He came up out of the ravine where the cattails whispered and the river forgot its name. A giant, they called him, because no other word made sense when he unfolded from the shadows like a crane from its operator’s shack. He had a bucket in one hand, a brush in the other. There was no smell of turpentine, just a flat darkness that didn’t glint, didn’t take the moon the way ordinary paint would. He hummed as he walked. On the pavement, he left heel-and-toe prints that looked like punctuation marks. His hum was tuneless, an argument with music. Women waiting at the bus stop by the shuttered bakery pressed closer together, jackets tugged tight. He didn’t rush. He never did. It was the slowness that nettled. He raised the brush, let it drip a black that wasn’t quite liquid, wasn’t quite shadow, and laughed without moving his open mouth. “Look at you,” he said, but not to any one of them, and when he flicked the brush, the air itself seemed to bruise. One of the women stepped forward, chin set, but a second woman caught her sleeve. The bus’s headlights rounded the corner, and in the brightness the giant’s dark looked blacker. He touched the bus shelter glass with two fingers and left a smear that the ad beneath couldn’t quite hold. “Small lights," he murmured. “You’re all small lights.” He did not touch their skin. He painted their reflections.

Mr. Winn watched from a kitchen window three floors up, her mug cooling on the sill, her heart thudding the familiar old thud that now and then skipped and then remembered itself. People in the building still called her Mr. because they always had, because she’d taught them math when they were younger and the habit clung like a chalk-smear. She was Winnifred in her passport, Win to the ones who dared, Mr. to everyone else, and she had stopped correcting them some time around her seventieth birthday when energy became a budget. She was eighty now. Her cane leaned against the microwave, a plaster saint in a family that didn’t believe. From here she could see the river, the bus stop, the narrow lots. She could see the man, if he was a man. She saw the way he inclined his head to listen for the bus’s brakes sighing, for the soft shuffle of sneakers. “You don’t get to make them small,” she told the glass, and her voice came out dry as a moth’s wing. The news had called him a giant because it kept children in their beds and adults at their desks. Giants were fairy-tale. The truth of him was worse, being not quite fairy, not quite tale.

The night the first video went viral, her granddaughter had texted at 3:12 a.m., a string of messages that didn’t quite form sentences. Mr. Winn had turned on the radio instead of the TV. She trusted the voices that kept company with storms. They said what they knew and left what they didn’t in the hush between weather and the farm report. A name, Bob. It was the demotic of terror, a nickname for a thunderhead. Bob had come from nowhere and everywhere, a man large enough to bend streetlights into bows, a figure in a too-long coat, a sound like a truck idling. He taunted women, the announcer said, no singsong lilt to the words, just a flat line of information. He painted them black—painted their coats, their hair, their shoes, the sidewalk beneath their feet, not with tar or oil but with a black that seemed to insist on itself. A mark. A shaming. Or something more ritual and more stupid. The line between prank and assault was a line he scuffed until it looked like there was no line at all. The radio voice went soft the way people do when they tell you your lab results aren’t what they hoped. The police had a grainy still. Anonymous tips clogged the hotline. Copycats had already begun, across a city nine hours ahead, across a campus three in the other direction. The math of fear is always exponential. One becomes two becomes eight’s echo.

“Mr.,” called Indira from the hall, knocking with the bent knuckle she used when she brought soup. “You shouldn’t stand in drafts.” “Then the drafts shouldn’t stand where I’m standing,” Winn said, but she stepped back anyway, smile tucked in. Indira’s face was lit with phone-light. “He’s down there,” Indira said, pointing like that would help, like Winn didn’t have eyes of her own. “He won’t come up,” Winn said. “Monsters like slopes.” “Is he a monster?” Indira asked, and Winn let the question be a saucer she put down on the table without answering. They stood, two women in a kitchen that still smelled faintly of last week’s onions. The refrigerator made the sound of a distant shore. “You can call someone,” Indira said. “Who would come?” Winn felt the old teacher rise in her throat, the tone she used to call a class back to itself. “They’ll come. They’re always late, and they always come.” “Do you think he knows we’re watching?” Indira whispered. “He wants the watching,” said Winn, and was surprised at the certainty in her own mouth.

The first time a copycat killed someone, it wasn’t on purpose, an anchor said later in a voice tuned to hush hysteria. It never is, the anchor added in tone if not in words, and someone had to go to the hospital for saying what she wasn’t allowed to. A young man in a hoodie had flung paint at a woman jogging at dusk along a seawall. She stumbled into traffic. A truck’s driver didn’t see. The numbers changed. They made the crawl at the bottom of every screen into a thicker rope. This is how it works, Mr. Winn thought, not for the first time. We name it. We feed it. It grows. In a grainy clip from Hamburg you could hear a man laughing: “We’re painting the night,” and a chorus of hoots, a laughter that sounded like coughs. In Lagos a woman sat on a stoop and wiped at her blackened hands with a dishcloth, her mouth a hard, white line, the camera recipient of her controlled fury. In Seoul a subway car stood with its doors open while maintenance crews swabbed at streaks that had seeped into the plexiglass like bruises remembering fists. The words were different because languages are, but the rhythm was the same. This was not just him anymore. This was a contagion that did not need a carrier now that the idea itself had a skeleton. Deaths rose in the way calculators do when your finger holds down a button too long.

Mr. Winn took out a notebook with a marbled cover and a list began without her permission. It was always like that. Lists were a reflex, a scratching itch. She wrote dates, times, locations, details that felt useful because they were small. “He hums,” she wrote. “No gasoline smell. No brush marks when he moves away.” She wrote: “He does not run. He is never earlier than the last bus. He looks up.” She had a friend on the force, or had had, years ago, a young officer who’d taken her class twice because math was a beast he wanted to domesticate. He was a detective now and wore his exhaustion like a well-cut suit. She still had his card, the printed number as irrelevant as a street address to a person who preferred bridges. She dialed him anyway. “Côté,” he said, his voice the same as always, a tree trunk. “It’s me,” she said, and waited for him to catch up. He did. “Mr. Winn,” he said, warmth tucked under the formalities. “I’ve got nothing to give you,” he began, and she cut him off. “I’m not asking for secrets,” she said. “I’m asking for your patience.” “That I have,” he said, and she could hear him set something down on a desk, the wafer of a coffee cup finding a ring. “He’s out there,” she said. “He’s everywhere,” Côté answered. “Tell your people to stay inside,” she told him, and then laughed because who were her people anymore? “We’ll increase patrols,” he said instead of the truth, and in the pause they both thought the same thought: late, late, late.

If the giant had a name before the feeds named him Bob, if he had a mother who held his wrist as they crossed the street and told him not to touch the wet paint on the porch railing, if he had a neighbor who took in his mail when he went away once, none of it mattered now. Now he was a rumor that wore boots. He thought in alternating currents. He walked with a patience learned from watching a river wreck its banks. He did not dream. Or if he did, the dreams were what the world called waking. His hatred was not personal; he would have told you that if you had asked him and stayed long enough to endure the answer. “It’s pattern,” he would have said, “it’s the smallness of your lights,” but what he meant was thrumming in his wrists, a music like a headache. Women turned the world. Women insisted on being suns. It offended him and that offense was his oxygen. He found a joy in making a gloss of the faces that would not shine for him, as though he could put night back where day had dared to nest. He had no slogans. He found them in the mouths of others, in the comments section that floated him like a sea supports a corpse. He didn’t need to be smart. He needed to be seen. He was very, very good at being seen.

For a time, after her husband died, Mr. Winn had logged in to rooms filled with strangers who remembered things. She found homes in the places where the records of old roads lived, in the corners of the internet where aerial photographs of towns in 1953 meant something to someone besides a city planner. She had a handle, m.r.w., and a reputation for accuracy. It turned out that the people who hunted lost deeds and collected abandoned maps were the same people who saw patterns before the police framed them. They had threads. They had spreadsheets that looked like quilts. “It’s a copycat cascade,” someone wrote. “Normalcy bias is broken, so they’ll try anything that looks like story,” wrote another, and Mr. Winn loved her for saying so. A person with a name that wasn’t quite a name—arkady—sent her a file. She had to pick it up like the old days, with more caution than necessary. It was a clip of a garage where someone had recorded a shadow as it went by. Not much. Lucid noise. But in the audio, under the thrum of a refrigerator, you could hear a low voice say, “Paint is confession.” She played it again and again until the phrase lost meaning and turned to rhythm. Paint is confession. Confession to whom? The last time she had confessed anything it had been to her daughter on a bench by the river: I cannot be the woman you need me to be. She had meant patience. She had meant stamina. She had meant: I am old. Her daughter had nodded and held her hand as though Mr. Winn were the child and not the other way around. It had been a good day.

When the night market came back to Kitchener after its winter break, the organizers posted signs promising extra security and foolishness at a minimum. The night smelled like sugar and charcoal. Mr. Winn went because she refused not to. She moved through the crowd like a ship through reeds, the cane making a percussive rhythm that kept her honest. Wachowski’s dumpling cart had a line like a pilgrim trail. A girl at a stall called CandleLit sold jars the size of fists with wicks braided like sailors’ knots. At the entrance, a police van idled, officers standing in pairs with the stiffness of people who want to be anywhere else. Mr. Winn found a bench made of three planks and a history of splinters. She let the crowd move around her. She had learned to be still. Around her, phones pointed at food and faces. The paint was obvious when it came because it did not catch the light. The giant did. He moved at the edge first, the way a storm tries out its voice before it takes to the center. A woman laughed too loudly at something in the next stall and the laughter cracked. He didn’t go for her. He reached for the canvas of a mural someone had commissioned for the event, a wash of bright oranges and blues, a woman’s face composed of flowers, a celebration, and with one calm swipe he salted it with night. The crowd hissed like a continent of kettles. He turned and the black he’d made seemed to expand, a wet blot on the eye.

“You don’t have a right to that,” Mr. Winn said, not sure whether she was talking to the art or the air around it. He heard her. Of course he heard her. He found her with an ease she found obscene, a snap of attention like a lighthouse beam falling square on a window that thought itself a secret. He smiled. He wasn’t young, but he wasn’t old. His face was the kind you forgot immediately while remembering forever the idea of it. He tipped his head at her, as if she’d told a joke that he liked. “You like rules,” he said. “I like boundaries,” she said. “They keep the wrong people out.” He raised the brush. He didn’t bring it close. He tapped it against his shoulder in a bored little rhythm. The black did not splatter. This was the thing that broke her heart more than anything: the black obeyed him. “You think names will help you,” he said. “They always have,” she said. He waited as if for a better answer and when none came, he turned away and trailed his brush along the ground in a line that the children would step over tomorrow as though it were the border between lands on a map.

Afterwards, in the wash of siren colors and the sizzle of indignation, people gave her credit she hadn’t earned. “You stood up to him,” said a young woman with a shaved head and a tattoo of a sparrow on her wrist. “I’m very tired,” said Mr. Winn, and meant it. Côté found her near the exit, his tie loosened, his face a cantilever of worry. “You shouldn’t have engaged,” he told her, the way a teacher tells a kid to keep hands flat on the desk. “He listens,” she said. “He listens to hear where the fear is,” Côté answered. “Then we’ll whisper,” she said. “Don’t make jokes,” he told her and then seemed to hear himself and smiled despite where they were. “We can’t get ahead of him,” he said, low. “We’re always reading his footprints.” “Because you keep pretending he’s singular,” she said. “He’s not one. He’s many, and he’s a story.” “We can’t arrest a story,” he said. “You can if it has a body,” she said, and the look he gave her was something like belief and something like grief. He wrote his new number on the back of her hand like anyone’s teenage friend and told her to call only if it mattered. “It always matters,” she said, and he ran a hand over his hair and didn’t answer.

The market closed a half hour early without calling it that. Everywhere, the faces of women had a new tightness to the mouth, a new swivel to the head on the neck. If you’d been dropped into that crowd from space you would have said: there are hawks above. News came in even before she got home. A hospital in Newark on lockdown. In Jaipur someone with a bucket and a bandanna had been chased across a roof and had fallen wrong. A vigil in Prague, candles under a statue that wore a shawl of soot. The counts became their own tally marks. The lines on the graphs found a steeper angle as though something had leaned its weight against them. Someone on Stoneflower posted a screenshot of the growth curve with the caption, “This is not natural” and Arkady answered, “Nothing viral needs to be natural once it’s taken root in minds.” Mr. Winn clicked and clicked until the numbers blurred and what remained was the thudding truth: this would get worse before worse became a measure too small to hold it.

In the morning, a thin envelope slid under her door. It had a stamp from a town she knew from the taste of its name. Bloom. A postmark like a scar. She sat. She was, if she was honest, a person who believed in omens if they came in the shape of the mail. The note inside had been typed on a machine that refused to give itself to the century. The letters had inconsistent ink, as though some of them had been loved more than others. Win, it read, which put a crack in her heart. Only three people wrote her that, and two of them were dead. The third was Lenka, who had left years ago for a prairie sky and never looked back. The note was four sentences. His paint isn’t paint. It’s the dark of a thing that eats light. Shadows can’t swim. Find where the river is deeper than he thinks. Then, in a smaller script, as though shameful: It will like me less for telling you. She pressed the paper to her mouth as if she could taste the place it had been written. Shadows can’t swim. Ridiculous. Useful. Most truths that mattered started as a thing you could only say slant.

She spent the day walking the city with the map of it superimposed on her brain like the overlay of a blue diagram. The river bent and split and gathered itself again. Bridges had personalities; some invited, some dared. At the iron footbridge by the old mill, graffiti had been layered so many times you could feel the strata with your fingertips, noble sediment of bored summers. She paused midspan and looked down into water that did not carry a perfect reflection but a rubbed-out version. Her cane leaned against the railing while her free hand held a thermos that had once belonged to her husband, a dent near the cap where the world had tried to whack it into another shape. “He wants a stage,” she told the wind. “He wants a chorus and he wants it to sing his tune.” She thought about the last bus stop before the bend, about the way the streetlights failed to reach the riverbank because budget was always what you thought you could hide beneath a word like prudence. It would have to be soon. The city could not keep holding its breath.

That night she didn’t sleep so much as catalog horizontal hours. She had a dream about a classroom with no desks, the students standing, faces upturned like sunflowers, only their centers were black and the petals dull. She woke with a sentence in her mouth: To solve a problem, you have to believe a solution exists. It wasn’t hers. It belonged to the textbooks she had flung away in disgust years ago. But a bad sentence can hold a good crumb, and she combed it. Believe a solution exists. Not a cure. Not a hero. A way. She found her boots. She found the key to the basement where the building’s old laundry sink held water cool as forgiveness. She filled two bottles and swung them into a bag. She put on the coat that didn’t mind rain. She wrote a note to Indira in case, because this is what you do when you leave the possibility of not returning. Hello I am taking a foolish walk. If I do not return, do not let them say I went quietly. She stuck it to the fridge magnet shaped like a pear.

The streets at midnight were a quieter kind of busy. A cat preluded her down the block and then ducked into a hedge as though embarrassed by its own company. A man in a parka walked a dog whose leash had LEDs that looked like a child’s bracelet. The river spoke in its many voices. Ahead, the bus stop kept its vigil. There was no bus scheduled now, but buses have their own rules about crisis, and she’d seen them roll up empty just to change the air. He would come. He had learned the schedule of their forgetting. Her cane struck sparks from the sidewalk in her mind, though it did no such thing in actual. She chose the far side of the shelter and stood where the bank sloped toward the water’s shoulder. She was not, she scolded herself, a brave woman. She was simply the one who had gone. That will have to do, she told the imaginary teacher who lived in her sternum. Across the river, a light went on in a house and then off again, the occupant making a decision that was none of her business.

She heard him before she saw him. Not footsteps. A shift in the night’s voltage. The kind of quiet that isn’t empty but taut. The black came with him. It was as if he had a shadow that had recruited other shadows and all of them waited for his signal to advance. He was tall as a story told by a liar. He stopped beside the shelter and considered the ad for a thrill show in some city that wore its noise like a crown. He set down his bucket. The black did not slosh. “You again,” he said without turning. “Me,” she said, and the sound was so inadequate she added, “I taught math,” as if competence could be an armor anyone would honor. He faced her then, and the brush lifted on its own as though a man had attached to it merely for show. “You don’t get to write the world,” he told her, and she didn’t answer because it seemed foolish to disagree about something like that. “You get to scribble,” he allowed. “You get to flick your little lights at each other and call it love.” “You came from somewhere,” she said, and surprised herself with the tear that rose and did not fall. He looked past her as if he had a more interesting student than this one. “Everything comes from somewhere,” he said. “So what.” He took a step toward her.

“Shadows can’t swim,” she said, softly, like a prayer you don’t admit to. He stopped. It was not the words; it was the posture of words. “Someone told you a joke,” he said. “It isn’t a bad one.” “It isn’t a joke,” she said. “And if it is, I’ve chosen to laugh at you and not with you.” “Do you think you can insult a tide?” he asked, and there was something close to admiration in it. “I know tides fail,” she said. “They fail to drown us every time.” He took another step. The slope behind her waited, a darker dark. Her hands were steady. She thought of the letters in Lenka’s note, some of them bold with habit. She thought of the little girl at the market with the sparrow tattoo who had said you stood up to him and had meant I wish I were you and had been wrong. “You don’t have to do this,” she told him, lying. “I do,” he said, and for the first time there was something in his voice like honesty. “I truly do.” The brush lifted, something in the air tense as the skin of milk in a warmed pot.

She stepped back. The bank was steeper than it looked, the grasses slick with the day’s leftover damp. The river took her ankle and then her knee. Cold wrote itself around her bones. She did not yell. He leaned forward, amused, but did not offer a hand. The dark around him thickened as if it took a breath. “Careful,” he said, mock concern a chord he could play well. She took another step back because she had committed to this, because retreat had become a kind of advance. The night rearranged itself in that moment into a diagram she could read. She felt the water pulling and the mud letting go. She smelled the city and the river and the paint that was not paint. The brush he held trembled, just slightly, as though it too had a pulse. He lifted it and extended it toward her, curious suddenly to see if the river would take the color the way walls did, if water could be made to admit his mark. He reached. She reached. His shadow tilled itself forward as a field does when a wind scythes it. And then—Chapter 2

And then the river did the oldest trick it knew, which was to be many things at once. It was a mirror smeared by thumbprints and a beast with a cold tongue and a ledger that remembered what fell into it. The tip of his brush hovered like a surgeon’s scalpel and when the black that was not paint reached for the water, the water reached back in a way that was not reach at all but refusal. The smear he teased toward her slid off the bristles as if embarrassed to be seen and went to lie on the surface with the smugness of oil until the current tugged and the thing that ate light discovered that the feast was not for it. It puckered. It shivered like skin under a voltage. It tried, with the insistence of a stubborn child, to remain itself and could not. What had always obeyed him made a sound that was not a sound but a feeling in her teeth and the smear tore, not into droplets but into absences that collapsed under their own lack and fell through.

He flinched for the first time since she’d seen him, a minute pull at the corner of his mouth as if a fish had tugged a hook buried there. His shadow did a strange mathematics, thinning away from the river’s edge as if the slope were a proof it had failed. He shifted his weight, surprised, and the bucket cocked against his shin. She did what she had carried water through ninety minutes of doubt to do. She dragged the bag up from the wet against her hip, worked the cap with fingers that had taught endless children to turn stubborn screw-tops, and flung a bright rope of water across the low air between them. It arced, so small a gesture against so much night, and struck the bristles first. The brush convulsed like a living thing. The black on it did not splash; it retreated, trying to knit itself back into the ferrule and finding no seam that would hold. The little runnels that made a face of him a moment ago—cheekbone shadow, socket, the hint of a jaw—lost their conviction.

He snarled without voice, the throat working as though he’d swallowed a burr. He reached for her with the empty hand, not for help but for the satisfaction of forward motion, and his boot bit into the grass and then into the mud that had planned this. She had planned this too; she took another back-step because sometimes the trap is the willingness to stumble. The river made a sound at her knee that, if you had no poetry, you would call glug and if you had too much, you would call invitation. She uncapped the second bottle, her hands remembering the thermos from her husband’s factory nights, the tin taste and the winter steam, and she poured again. This time she went for the line where his darkness lay on the ground like fabric. The water, which was only water and did not know itself as weapon or mercy, ran into the black and the black thinned again like a rumor encountering fact.

He tried to draw the brush back and found that he could not do it clean. Fibers clung, or not fibers, whatever the shadow’s equivalent of hair might be, tugging like weed-roots. For a heartbeat he was a boy in a backyard with a too-strong kite tugging at him, the wind not physics but will. He stepped after it out of habit and the bank, with the impartiality of a ledger, subtracted him a degree of balance. The bucket went over. It did not pour; it leaned and the dark inside of it tried to decide whether to answer gravity like a liquid or like a position held by a soldier. In the indecision the river found opportunity. It pulled, which is to say it recited its catechism of down, and the lip of the bucket kissed the surface and the thing in the bucket made a noise like a string snapped back on a cello and then lost shape.

To call what happened next panic would be to reduce the moment to a nervous system. He did not flail. He did something worse, which was to calculate and lose. His hand tightened on the brush, the way a person grips a talisman that has never once warranted such faith. The black that had always loved him, if love is obedience, wavered as his shadow did, its edges feathering where the river breathed. He had never looked young to her and he did not now, but the set of his shoulders admitted confusion in the language of muscle. He stepped away from the water and discovered that away had contracted. The strip of grass that had been his dry stage was a scarf, a belt, something narrow that had lost pretension to breadth. His laugh, when it came, had no shape to it. It was the laugh of a man in an elevator that has stopped between floors, hands empty, the plan a mist.

She was cold to the hip now and her joints were giving her their old lecture, but she’d made promises to herself in the hours the dream with the sunflower faces had eaten. She stayed. She did again the small thing that the large thing disliked. She sloshed what remained along the toe-space of him, a line not at his body but at the insistence outside his body that dressed him. The sound it made didn’t repeat; it never repeated. This time it was almost relief, like a sighed yes in a sleeping room. Shadows can’t swim, Lenka had typed, and here was the footnote: they could drown or they could be rinsed away or they could snap back hard and cut. When a piece of his dark tore free and fell into the river, it made a hole where the night should have been and then the hole filled with an ordinary mid-March black. She watched the absence remembering itself into one more stripe of water.

He did not run. He shed. He let go of the brush all at once and when it hit the bank it did the worst possible thing, which was nothing. It lay like a stick. It had become a stick. Something in him swarmed, the way hornets braid when their home is kicked. He reached for the bucket and thought better of it, for the first time honoring the river. He took a step back and the knife of mud on his boot tried to cut a second step from the bank and could not. The slim humiliation of it was visible even in the dark. He looked at her as if she had relieved him of a coat and then refused to give it back, as if she had revealed an indecency. “Small lights,” he said, but the words had no doctrine in them; they were rote. He tugged at the hem of his too-long coat as if to arrange a dignity that would travel and then walked the slow backward line he walked when he was on a stage he had not chosen.

Mr. Winn stood still until the cold worked its way through the brave and down to the practical. Her left foot was a complaint she could not ignore and the river, which respected no plan but its own, lifted a little to see if her hip might want to be a rock. She came up out of the water fox-slow, all calculation about which leg deserved to be first, the cane in a loop of strap around her wrist saving itself for the moment it would be more friend than emblem. She watched him cross the sidewalk, his shadow shortened, pinned to his heels like a one-sentence apology. He left no heel-and-toe punctuation now, just the plain grammar of boots. The bucket stayed upended, the brush a stick, the black in the grass a kind of bruise that did not spread, the night adjusting to an absence it had not known it had arranged around a man.

The bus that pulled up then was one of the hybrids, a hummed contralto riding under its breath. The driver saw her and in the space between habit and policy threw the lever that made his bus lower its knee. He came down two steps and then paused, taking in the river, the toppled things, the woman sopping at the edge of what could only look like a bad idea come to teach a class in consequences. “You all right, ma’am?” he asked, which was what he had to ask to unlock any other sentence. “I will be,” she said, which was the only answer she could trust. There were two passengers. One of them cried quietly without any connection to this scene, the kind of tired we never legislate; one of them held a bag of groceries like a baby. The driver looked past her into the dark the way you look at a dog that might or might not come when you call its name. “You want a blanket?” he asked, and when she nodded he went into the belly of the bus and came back with a roll of orange wool that smelled—to her surprise—like clean sun.

By the time she got herself up the stairs in her building, leaving wet on each step the way a snail leaves a slick, she had made a new list in the recess where lists live. The headings were simple, the subpoints anything but. Water interrupts. Running water eats edges. The brush is not tool; it is permission. The bucket and the brush, when unaccompanied by him, revert to the world. He is bound to the thing or the thing is bound to him in the old way of stories and belts. She peeled off her wet pants in the kitchen, because it was nearer the radiator and because the kitchen had always been the bravest room in any place she’d lived, and wrapped herself in the orange bus blanket for twenty civilized minutes. Then she got up, because reward is not a plan, and put the stick-that-was-a-brush and the upended bucket into the galvanized basin in the basement. She did not touch them with naked hands. It was the sort of precaution best left unspoken if you wanted anyone to take your scientific habits seriously.

Côté arrived with the morning in his face, thread-tracks where sleep had been and left. He knocked three times and then two, the way people do when they’ve practiced their courtesy. When she opened the door, he did the count in his head you only see when someone who is stubborn has done a sensible thing, and he nodded as if to say: I choose not to lecture you because it would cost too much coin from a purse you don’t carry. “You look like someone who fell in a story,” he said, and she made the shape of a laugh. He went to the sink without asking because the years let you and took the kettle from the stove and refilled it and set it back as if tea were as tactical as everything else he had learned to do. She told him and he wrote nothing down because the words made enough of a pattern without ink. When she got to the part where the brush became a stick, he put a hand to his mouth, not to hide surprise but to keep it from running off.

They went down to the basement together as if it were a ritual, the kind where you go toward the thing to make it less holy. The basin sat like a font someone had scooped out of the wrong religion. The bucket leaned and didn’t drip. The stick lay across it with the boredom of a ruler on a desk. Afterwards, the airport director sat on a bench with Mr. Winn and let her head fall back to look at the ceiling, which was dull and dimpled like the underbelly of a whale in photographs. “I hate that we did something smart,” she said, and then clarified, because she was an honest woman when allowed to be: “I hate that we had to.” Mr. Winn said nothing because it is not polite to tell a person: you are living the moment when you discover that competence is merely the beginning. Indira handed out cups because she had insisted on bringing them, because she had written Bring cups! in pen on a flyer and pens are for this. Arkady sat on the floor in a way that suggested her bones were jointed differently than other people’s and rubbed her eyes under her glasses with the heel of her hand like a person bargaining with a headache. Côté took a call he did not want and afterward he said to no one and everyone: he’ll try the dam or he’ll try the places where wheels never stop. “We cannot flood a bridge,” someone said, and Mr. Winn said, “Maybe we can.”

He went to the river that night because he had nowhere else to go that would speak to him without sarcasm. The water looked up at him with its usual attention span, which is to say it did not hold a grudge and it did not forget. He stared at the dam and thought as hard as he could, which was a kind of apology, a child’s offering of effort. He imagined a dozen ways to make a wound in it and his mind lapped at each the way a tongue laps at a sore tooth. A man came and stood twenty yards away and put a cigarette in his mouth and then did not light it. They shared the silence the way two dogs share the shade of a small tree: without making rules about it. He thought about leaving because men like him always think there is a city somewhere that will not make them work this hard for attention. He imagined deserts. He liked the word because it didn’t ask you to learn the trick of its spelling until too late and he appreciated any word that resented correction.

At home, Mr. Winn told her kitchen about conveyance because kitchens are where movement begins in a house, in pots, in kettles, in drawers that slide because someone cared enough to get the rails right. They had learned to run water through the evening and to make light misbehave. They had learned to be a crowd that did not become mob. She made a list that had no bullets because this was not war and yet had the smell of it. She wrote: belts, fans, lungs. She wrote: buses lower for old bones—ask the drivers to linger the way they do when the woman with a walker needs a second. She wrote: the dam is not an enemy; it is a rhythm that can be interrupted without revenge. She wrote: the story is a river too; stop feeding it names and the fish will have to learn to eat plants. Her hand hurt when she’d finished and she pressed the heel of it into her own palm and felt the pulse that had been Teddy’s and thought about what it means for an old body to return to a fight one last time and find it still knows every step.

Lenka came as lightly as a letter when she did, months late and exactly on time, and the knock she made on the door was the sort made by someone who has calculated the cost of being turned away and will still call it a bargain if it happens. She stood on the thresh and two women whose hair remembered different climates looked each other into the present. They did not hug because there are reunions that deserve patience, and because both of them had learned that any abruptness invites the body to do things it will later resent. They sat because sitting is a discipline. Lenka’s face had made decisions without asking her, which is what faces do when we turn our attention to the state of the world and away from mirrors. “Conveyors,” she said, and laughed until her eyes found water that had nothing to do with misters. “You always did take my homework too seriously,” Mr. Winn answered, and their tea was exactly the right temperature, as if a cue had been thrown from a booth.

The night market returned like a child who has learned a new word it can’t stop repeating, and the organizers threaded lines above the stalls that tugged bits of foil in breeze. The dumpling cart steamed its offerings like small fogs and young men in shirts with sleeves rolled carefully to the elbow leaned beside it trying to remember why they had decided this was handsome. The bus shelter at the edge had a different photograph in it now, a picture of a woman in a hard hat smiling not at the camera but at something to its left, as if she were getting a joke no one had told and it still amused her. He stood across the street and weighed the market with his eyes the way an angler weighs a stream, and then he did something that nearly hurt her more than the things he had loved to do. He turned away. He did not want to perform where the stage had learned him. He wanted a new audience, though he would never admit that the word he really meant was victim. The city felt the way you feel when you see a hawk change course; it means salvation for some small birds and it means later for others.

They practiced silence in a way that nearly felt religious if you did not bring God to it. The drop pins multiplied but they did not add glitter to themselves, which was a kind of discipline that impressed Mr. Winn. People filmed less; or if they filmed, they handed their footage to Stoneflower without posting, and the site accepted the work the way a river accepts a piece of bread thrown to it by a toddler who believes in ducks. The anchors learned a new tone—one that reported without rendering—and when a woman in a newsroom slipped and said his name, her cohost touched her forearm lightly to say: remember, we have learned not to feed the river with that. The police, who had been forced by their funding and by their pride into pretending that water curtains were not part of law, began to carry hose couplers with the same absentminded ease with which they had always carried pens. In the laundromat, they pinned a new schedule near the coin machine, not of washing cycles but of shifts for the misters near the university tunnel, and the sound of quarters dropping into the slot had never been so companionable.

He went inland in his mind. He stood in a warehouse where boxes moved on belts he could not see the ends of and thought about what it would be like to make those belts hate themselves. He imagined painting the packages not with black but with the habit of hesitation. He lifted the brush and he drew a line on the metal lip of a chute and for a split second the line pretended it had a future. Then the chute shook the way a throat does when laughter will not be held and the line fractured, ran, and became a question that did not want his answer. He put the brush to the floor and felt ridiculous and did not like the feeling and did it again in spite of himself because sometimes practice is just cruelty that cannot climb. He was not a man given to private prayers, but he discovered a superstition in himself that had been waiting for an invitation: he began to walk with his palm pressed to things that held motion and to feel for their pulse, as if he could borrow it.

Mr. Winn dreamed of rivers whose names she had known when she was young and studying geography not because she believed in empire but because she understood that if you are going to fight anything you ought to know its shape. The Volta braided itself with the Grand, and a creek that had been nothing but a dysfunction behind her childhood school offered her a gold coin it made out of a pop-top. She woke with the sentence that she had disliked when it came in a textbook: calculate your losses now so that you will not be surprised. She put coffee on because she could and she sat at the table because it was there and she used a pen that had trouble starting because the ink had been allowed to think too long and she made two columns. On one side, she wrote what he had not yet done, because even monsters have boundaries they do not know they honor. On the other, she wrote what they had learned to do not because any of them were brave but because practice had made them competent. In the middle, she left a strip of paper blank and didn’t name it anything, because sometimes you have to leave the river a place to run that is not through your house.

When the rain came, it came wrong. It came sideways first, and then it came in the tight fists that make gutters forget their jobs. It came hard enough that a woman on television said the word biblical without irony and then apologized to no one because she had meant it. The dam held in the way good engineering does, which is to say it did not ask to be admired. Downstream the river took liberties it had not asked permission for in years. A man in a red car stalled his engine in the middle of the underpass and it looked for all the world like an expensive toy being baptized against its will. Volunteers moved their misters into basements and pointed them at stairwells because there is no rule that says a river cannot run up for a while if you give it a little help. He stood on a bridge that the city had not thought to test with the elegance of feet and remembered that he had once laughed at the idea that water could be asked to do a job.

It was never a victory. That would have required the neatness of endings and this was an age of edits. It was, instead, a ritual they learned to keep. Volunteers with cups, and a patch of foil in a child’s backpack that made a bright constant noise as he ran, and a traffic cop who turned hydrants at the quarter hour the way he’d been told and added a minute because he could feel in his knee that the dark was near. It was an old woman with a cane who did not change the city so much as she taught it to use a set of muscles it had not known it still had. It was a man who had mistaken hunger for map learning to stand in doorways he used to stride through and feel, for the first time in his adult life, the press of other people’s pace against his own. It was a story that had thought itself a river learning it could be dammed by silence, by misters, by the sound of a bus lowering a knee for bones and lifting again. It was not enough. It was, which is what the world offers most days, more than yesterday and hard-won.Chapter 6

Spring came in increments that felt like a child counting too fast, and the city tried to keep up without spraining anything important. Leaves went from coins to hands. Potholes blossomed with the annual arrogance of things that know you will forgive them because you must. The river moved from a winter sermon to a conversational tone, and in its voice you could hear the work of all those small pumps and misters and buckets that had been enlisted into a militia nobody had planned on forming. Mr. Winn had a new way of keeping time, a practice that would have made her former self roll her eyes, and it went like this: how many buses bowed for bones today, how many hydrants sighed for six minutes, how many belts hummed their quiet hymn. Numbers gave her nerves a place to sit. They stayed on their chairs more often now.

In the council chamber with its bad flags and its chairs that seemed designed to make backs suspicious of sitting, she sat at a microphone and did not let her hands perform. The councilor who liked to be first had introduced her as a citizen scientist which was not a thing she was and yet had its uses in that room. She had put on a jacket that could pretend to authority and had tucked her cane up beside the desk so as not to let anyone offer to help her with what she did not need help with. “We are not at war with water,” she said, and heard in her own voice the old teacher who could insist a problem had a solution because the children would be safer if they believed it. “We are not at war with him, either, if you mean by war that we make him larger to feel ourselves brave. This is a maintenance problem. It is a city problem. It is the problem of keeping things moving when fear would like to stop them.” She laid out her lists in the language of budgets because that is a dialect politicians will always meet you in a hallway to speak. When she reached the part where she asked for the sprinklers in the underpass to be switched from ornamental to tactical, the councilor who wore disapproval like a starched shirt sighed audibly and asked about costs like a man who has never met a life that counted more than a line of numbers. She did not tell him that he had miscounted his own value; she explained graywater again with the patience of someone who would prefer not to die on this hill and then die anyway if required.

Afterward in the hallway, the first-to-know councilor confided that a marketing firm had approached her about the drops. “We could make it a campaign,” the woman said, showing the whites of her eyes the way nervous horses do when a plastic bag blows in a yard. “We could put sponsors on the misters. We could sell branded umbrellas that actually catch the—” and then she stopped because even she could hear the word and its weight. “I don’t know how to tell you this kindly,” Mr. Winn said, and realized she didn’t much care whether kindness was necessary, “but you cannot merchandise a boundary. Leave us the plainness of it. Let the drops be unhandsome. Let there be no mascot.” The woman nodded the way people nod when they have already chosen, and Mr. Winn could see the pins with their gloss finish and their tidy fonts, and she could see also the first fundraiser held under a tent in a gated backyard while gardeners made the hedges pretend to be forest. She went home more tired than she had expected to be.

Tiredness, which had always been a companion, learned a new trick. It found her in bright places and asked to sit in her lap. She could be content one minute arranging the bowls in the drainer by size—the geometry of drying a religion she had never betrayed—and the next her heart would write its old skipping signature so elaborately that her hands would go cold. The doctor’s warning about best companions needing to go quiet occasionally came back like a tune she didn’t like but could not stop humming. On a Tuesday that had promised to be ordinary from the way the radio announcer said the name of the month, she set a cup down on the table too hard and the sound made a hole in her attention large enough that she had to sit before the floor remembered it was not a lake. Indira came with a kind firm mouth and a set of keys in her hand as if she might need to drive a thought somewhere that couldn’t get there on its own. They went to the clinic and the nurse at the counter said, “Hi, Mr. Winn,” in that easy way that says I am not going to argue with anyone’s name, and they orchestrated a day out of blood pressure cuffs and a machine that recorded heartbeats with a pencil that was not a pencil. She watched the pencil make the mountain range of her chest on paper and wondered how many peaks an old woman is allowed.

Côté met them in the lobby because his beat now included any place where the city’s air changed its mind. He held the elevator for them with a hand that refused to be dramatic about it and they rode up in a box where the mirror had no bruises, only a film you could not see, and the smudge of someone's hand that had been wiped away by a person who would go home after midnight and sleep with their socks on. “He came,” the guard said from the desk where the calls make their low tide noise. “He came and he tried to make the door forget itself and it did not.” They watched the security footage because that’s what we do when the world has found a way to imitate myth; we seek proof in pixels and in the slowed-down version where sometimes you can catch intention in the way a shoulder lifts. He looked the same as he always did—merely large, the way a resented chore is large—and he did the same thing he always did, the not-touch that is a violation precisely because it doesn’t need your skin. The door remembered itself. It remembered the joke of the hydrophilic film. It remembered that it was the kind of door that would always open for a woman with a folded sweater and a paper with a lab number on it and that it would sulk and refuse him as long as the city fed it that memory. He held his two fingers on the glass for a long time, as if he had found a nerve in it he could hold, and then he laughed, not loudly, just enough to make the light in the camera wobble as if laughter had mass. He left without a flourish, the worst insult he could give to his own appetite.

The night after, Stoneflower organized what Arkady insisted on calling the Hush Walk, a phrase that made Mr. Winn wince until she saw what the words had bought them. No signs, because slogans are bait. No chant, because chants want microphones. They walked the usual route that protests take through the downtown, that strangely ceremonial line that makes a city remember where its edges are. They wore foil that bent the light with all the subtlety of a cheap disco, not because anyone wanted to be festive but because it unsettled his shadow’s certainty about where to lay its head. They carried cups because Indira had written it on a flyer and because a woman in the third row had brought a thermos of broth and had learned that if you offer a thing hot and honest enough people will throw away their pride. Children wheeled those little fans on sticks that spin themselves silly and their parents made faces like they were worried about readiness and then stopped because readiness is a habit that either grows or doesn't and fear has never watered it properly. The only noise besides feet and the small machines was the bus that kneeled at each stop along the route even when no one asked because the driver was in on it and because mercy, when it practices, makes rituals beautiful.

He did not show himself that night, which did not mean he wasn’t there. He had learned to study the city the way a predator studies the waterholes on a nature program, the careful patience that is really just a refusal to work harder than hunger demands. He watched the foil make the shadows jitter and remembered boys with cameras at concerts holding their phones up like rosaries to music they believed in without knowing what belief costs. He walked parallel to them three streets over and hummed his wrong hymn and let the black he wore dribble onto the walls of a quiet lane where no one would see until morning, the vandalism equivalent of muttering. A man sweeping his stoop along that lane stepped accidentally into the run of it and found that his boot did not carry the mess the way tar would have. He was spared the humiliation of tracking a stain into his kitchen, and he went inside and told no one because he did not yet know it was a story. The city learned in those little unwitnessed mercies as much as in any coordinated act.

Mr. Winn’s granddaughter came to one Hush Walk with a friend whose jacket was the loud yellow of an idea you refuse to let anyone squint at and their hands stayed near each other not because they were afraid but because contact is a river too. They walked beside Mr. Winn for a block and a half and then went ahead in the natural rhythm of young and old bodies, and a thing happened that Mr. Winn would have called coincidence if she had not been in a season when coincidence felt like instrument. The mist from a mister caught the light from a streetlamp and made a veil across an alley mouth and in that veil stood a shadow waiting to be invited to be bold. It reached for her girl with an old reflex and found itself hesitating, not because of the water alone but because her girl was moving with other girls, a small crowd, and the tide of them would have made any paint choose to cling to one and not another and the indecision killed it. The black hesitated, faltered, sought a surface larger than a pocket, and then slunk back to his boots as if embarrassed. Later the granddaughter sent three messages with no words and a picture of the alley and a sentence: it was smaller when we were together, and perhaps this is what coming of age looks like under new rules.

When the first branded drop pins showed up on a city employee’s lanyard six weeks later, they were plain enough that the temptation to sneer passed without incident. The firm, it turned out, had contained within it a woman who had understood the assignment. The pins were matte. They did not glint. They had a small scratchable texture that made anxious hands calm down, and inside the pin behind the enamel a very cheap disc of foil moved when you moved, only a little, only enough to make light misbehave microscopically. The councilor who had wanted mascots sent an email saying see? and Arkady sent back three words that had the weight of a poem: you did not ruin. Later, at a farmer’s market that had become an impromptu clinic for useful things, Mr. Winn watched a man who had worked a night shift rub his thumb over one of those drops and put his shoulders down an inch and buy tomatoes that were too expensive and go home to sleep with less noise in his hair.

The man they had refused to name discovered that being thwarted repeatedly was not as interesting as he had hoped, and something in him that had practiced waiting went bad. He grew sloppy. In a library where the air is always cool in the way of places that harbor memory, he slid two fingers along a display case holding a map of the city drawn when millers and Mennonites had first agreed about bridges. The black tried to make the paper forget itself and failed in the precise square where the volunteer on duty had wiped it that morning with a cloth dipped in a little diluted detergent and water and a little prayer uttered beneath a breath. He did not like defeat in corners. He shied from that square the way animals learn to shy from electric fences when the shock has no poetry and therefore is terrifying. He went for the plexiglass instead and watched the swirls of his not-paint bunch at the fasteners and then retreat as if legal counsel had been called.

There was talk of drought. The weather app rearranged its icons into a gallery of suns that had no right to be smug, and people at bus stops said, “Well, at least we’ll have the beach,” in that false-bright tone that always accompanies small preemptive submissions. Public Works sent another letter. Use less, it said again, and this time the people with hoses made faces because they had grown to love the feeling of agency you get when water leaves you on purpose. Mr. Winn looked at her lists and felt that familiar clutch in her chest that is not fear but math, the calculation of what can be spared. She made a plan with Arkady that involved the thing they had learned at the airport: moving boundaries do not require volume. She wrote letters to the building supers and to the custodians whose respect she had always coveted more than a principal’s and she explained fans and foil and bead curtains in the language of maintenance and utility and cleaning budgets, and the custodians loved her not because she made their work glamourous but because she had noticed that theirs is the labor upon which any ritual stands. They set box fans at the mouths of corridors and hung light chains of reflective strips a child had cut from Mylar blankets in an art class from hooks that had been bored long ago for Christmas wreaths. The air became a river lazy enough not to be wasteful and noisy enough to unsettle shadow.

He tried to be clever and went to the parks not for the women but for the monuments, an escalation hidden in taste. He dragged his brush along a bronze shoe the size of a dog and watched the black slip and fail and gather in a seam where a sculptor had offered it shelter. He liked the idea of mocking metal because metal pretends to permanence, and he drew a line up the side of a soldier issued by history for pious purposes. There, too, the city had anticipated him, not with film but with the simplest of all acts: washing. A boy in a volunteer’s vest sprayed the statue with a bottle that had once held cleaner for kitchens and the black did that little soundless pop that meant it had gotten confused about what surface it was on. He turned and there in the distance he saw foil ribbon in birches and Mylar fish hung from a line like holiday in a language no one speaks anymore. His hum drooped. He had not expected tree-light to betray him.

At night, when she allowed herself the old bad habit of imagining conversation with a person who had harmed her city, she stopped offering him education and began offering him boredom. She pictured saying: we will not chase you. We will not film you. We will maintain without telling you. You will find doors that do not love you and corridors that breathe wrong and rails that are always a little damp when you are near. She would prefer to leave him to his hunger rather than feed it with outrage like sugar water. She did not try the speech on the air because speaking out loud has gravity; it pulls worlds into being. She spoke it into the steam above her kettle and felt the plea go up with it, a small weather making a roof under the big weather. Then she turned off the radio because even voices she trusted had begun to speculate again, and speculation is delicious and lazy and makes you feel like you have done something when you have not.

Lenka, who had come and stayed as if the city were a sofa you can nap on regardless of who pays the rent, wrote her third note at the table without ceremony. The ribbon of typing had become more exhausted; the e looked chewed by a mouse. Breath is a river if you let it be, she wrote, and smiled that the page could hold a sentence so silly and so exact at the same time. Mr. Winn thought about lungs and about the fans and about the whisper at the airport and she thought about the first time she had been told to blow out a candle on a birthday cake and had not understood until her father had bent his head and demonstrated and had grinned at her because men with grease on their fingers get to be tender only when something needs teaching that looks like a trick. She met Arkady at the pool and they watched the humidity rise on the glass like intent and they tested again with a line and a breath and found that exhale is not water but is disobedient enough to be useful. They taught the volunteers the trick of breathing across a threat and laughed because it felt like magic when it was only physics and felt like prayer when it was only practice repeated until the body adopts it.

He tried the tunnels beneath the university because he had once been young there and had learned to be lonely in exactly those fluorescent corridors. He had sworn not to return because vows are another kind of hunt for attention, and he went anyway because hunger breaks not just laws but self-respect. The air was not right. It moved in a way that made his darkness let go with tiny reluctant noises even though no one human could hear them. It shifted with the implacability of a schedule. Bead curtains said silly to his eye and then took from him the certainty he had in his own outline. Students walked by with their heads in midterms and their hands on straps of backpacks and he reached for one and his own shadow favored the bead curtain instead and slid along it, furtive and caught, like a lizard on a hot day choosing a line of shade and finding it ambush. He took the stair and the mechanical breath of the building met him in the air at his face and he had the first honest thought he had had in years: I am not wanted here. He had known it before. He felt it now at the level of blood.

When Indira’s niece made the poster about conveyances with little drawings of belts and fans and buses and breath, they put it up in the laundromat and in the vestibule at the clinic and at the checkout at Wachowski’s dumplings and in the locker room at the pool where children learned to be fish in water that professionals call too cold and mothers call fine. The poster was not art and was not design; it was instruction wearing its only good clothes. People took pictures of it to send to parents in cities where the dark had found new homes and those parents wrote back with the tone of people who have been thrown a rope and are too proud to say thank you and too human not to mean it. One city added bicycle wheels to the list and strung foil through the spokes and told their couriers and their gig economy and their kids to keep pedaling, keep moving, keep the boundary as river. A woman in a town where the river had been entombed under streets went into the tunnels and stood at a grate and felt the air that had once been water and told the air what she needed from it with the authority of a person who has been told no more times than math should allow.

There were setbacks and they did not give them headlines because headlines grew the wrong seeds. A basement flooded with ordinary water and the woman who lived there sat on her stairs and cried because she had had enough now of metaphors turning literal. A sprinkler jammed and a boy slipped and his wrist had a story to tell it hadn’t asked for. A vendor at the night market doused a line of foil fish with a hose and sheeted a woman who had not wanted to be wet and the apology was not graceful and the two women did not like each other for a week. The man who had been the center of this learned to come from the side, his favorite trick, and at dawn one morning put lines of not-paint in the place where the path narrows past the canal and three joggers stamped through it and one of them did not notice until she got home because sometimes you do not notice until after and then the fury is for your own attention as much as for the indifference of strangers. The city corrected where it could and learned to say we cannot fix that one and learned to say it with the right amount of regret and no glamour.

There was talk, again, of names. Journalists like to write referents. Parents of daughters wanted to know what to tell their children to call him so that the danger could be contained by a syllable the way childhood monsters are. Arkady wrote a fragment on Stoneflower and the thread took it and fed it and sent it back undistorted, which doesn’t happen often enough to be taken for granted: call the acts, not the actor. Call the harm, not the man. Call the habit, not the myth. Mr. Winn added for herself: call your friends before you go out at night and tell them which route is the one with the misters and the fans. The radio learned to say incident. The anchors learned to say interruption. The city learned to argue about nothing for a news cycle and then forget in favor of whether the dumpling cart should be moved nearer the entrance. Mr. Winn allowed herself the small luxury of getting bored of the right things.

He went to a church on a Tuesday afternoon when the light pours through windows only maintenance sees, and he sat in the back where men who do not trust themselves to be seen go. The holy water had become less obliging; the bowl sweated in a way it did not used to, and the priest who wore a collar that had not yet wilted nodded at him without invitation and did not stand on ceremony, which is its own ceremony. He put his hand near the surface and his shadow came off like a coat and tried to lie on the water and the water did not accept the burden, which is perhaps the closest thing to grace the city had witnessed in months. There was silence of a sort that has velocity and he understood without feeling that understanding in his mind that the thing he had loved most about himself—the obedience of his tool, the way it made the world more compliant—had been sold out by an element that had too many birthdays for anyone to count. He pulled back and he left, and the priest added no notch to any weapon and did not count coup and only wrote, on paper older than the computer in his office, a sentence about how the church had done an ordinary thing on a day that had asked for one.

Mr. Winn’s heart did its show on a day when the heat had tried to be more interesting than it deserved, and she sat at her window and breathed like she had taught dormitory girls to breathe during exams. Slow in, say hello to the edges. Slower out, tell the body there is more time than it thinks. Indira came without knocking and put a glass of water in her hand and a damp cloth at the back of her neck and did not ask whether she had taken any pills because questions sometimes lie down across the doorway and make what you need to do a step higher. It passed in the way storms pass after scaring you into naming your gods, and when she could count to sixty without losing track she said, “I would like to plant something,” in a tone that startled even her because she had not expected to want anything that large again. They went to the roof because the garden down the block had wait lists longer than desire and because the roof was where buckets collect rain and where women keep bats they are not supposed to have. They put basil into a plastic tub that had once held sports equipment no one needed, and when they watered it they did it with a zeal that would have made a saint blush. The basil did not mind the mixed motives. It took what was offered and tried leaves because trying is what plants do.

He tried, once, to speak. Not because anything had softened in him or in the city but because the hunger for attention is a sister to the hunger for confession; both are mouths. He stood on a platform not far from where he had once drawn lines on concrete for children to hop and he opened his actual mouth. “You live like you deserve to,” he said to no one in particular, and then waited for the thrill he had expected to feel in himself and did not. Two teens in the shelter pretended they had not smiled at each other a moment before, and a man with a paper bag of groceries read each of the ingredients on the back of a cereal box because that list demanded more loyalty than a madman’s sermon. He tried again, and he said, “You make your little lights,” not as a taunt but as a diagnosis, and the words met the hydrophilic film and slid down and pooled on the sill and had the decency to vanish without theater. He did not shout. He did not perform. He left, and the bus came, and the driver lowered the bus and the woman with the walker stepped on without needing anyone to clap.

Lenka brought her a book of river names. It had been put from print somewhere in the decade when publishers had forgotten that there was such a thing as quite a lot of people who liked to remember geography for its own sake. They sat with it and an index card and they took turns saying the names out loud and wondering whether their mouths made a kind of river when they did. “Orinoco,” Lenka said, and the O’s made their lips into boats. “Saskatchewan,” Mr. Winn said, and the consonants went on little journeys between teeth. They did not pretend it was medicine. They let it be the comfort it was. Later that night Mr. Winn slept and dreamed a map on which the drop pins were not pins at all but mouths of springs, and when she woke she felt a stupid tenderness for the pipes in the walls. She told the radiator how much she appreciated its civic attitude. She told the sink she valued its valves. She refrained from telling the toilet anything because the toilet had been forced to play too many roles lately and deserved a day free of symbolism.

It did not end because things do not. There were weeks where the graphs leaned south and weeks where they hesitated at the zero line like swimmers at the end of a lane not sure whether to make the turn or rest a hand on the wall. The drought pinched and the basil on the roof looked at the sun with an expression that could only be read as aside, and Mr. Winn and Indira took to carrying water up the stairs in a way that made them laugh at themselves and at gravity. In letters that leaned worse now because the typing ribbon in the secondhand shop had given up on its vocation, Lenka wrote about lungs. Autumn finally found its footing after so much summer that felt like a dare. The air came thin and edged, a blade for heat’s rope, and the smoke that had made the sky its rented room took down its curtains and apologized by way of distance. Mr. Winn walked with the crowd and let the noise wash the old stubbornness in her chest in a way that annoyed her by feeling too much like cure.
