He came up out of the ravine where the cattails whispered and the river forgot its name. A giant, they called him, because no other word made sense when he unfolded from the shadows like a crane from its operator’s shack. He had a bucket in one hand, a brush in the other. There was no smell of turpentine, just a flat darkness that didn’t glint, didn’t take the moon the way ordinary paint would. He hummed as he walked. On the pavement, he left heel-and-toe prints that looked like punctuation marks. His hum was tuneless, an argument with music. Women waiting at the bus stop by the shuttered bakery pressed closer together, jackets tugged tight. He didn’t rush. He never did. It was the slowness that nettled. He raised the brush, let it drip a black that wasn’t quite liquid, wasn’t quite shadow, and laughed without moving his open mouth. “Look at you,” he said, but not to any one of them, and when he flicked the brush, the air itself seemed to bruise. One of the women stepped forward, chin set, but a second woman caught her sleeve. The bus’s headlights rounded the corner, and in the brightness the giant’s dark looked blacker. He touched the bus shelter glass with two fingers and left a smear that the ad beneath couldn’t quite hold. “Small lights," he murmured. “You’re all small lights.” He did not touch their skin. He painted their reflections.

Mr. Winn watched from a kitchen window three floors up, her mug cooling on the sill, her heart thudding the familiar old thud that now and then skipped and then remembered itself. People in the building still called her Mr. because they always had, because she’d taught them math when they were younger and the habit clung like a chalk-smear. She was Winnifred in her passport, Win to the ones who dared, Mr. to everyone else, and she had stopped correcting them some time around her seventieth birthday when energy became a budget. She was eighty now. Her cane leaned against the microwave, a plaster saint in a family that didn’t believe. From here she could see the river, the bus stop, the narrow lots. She could see the man, if he was a man. She saw the way he inclined his head to listen for the bus’s brakes sighing, for the soft shuffle of sneakers. “You don’t get to make them small,” she told the glass, and her voice came out dry as a moth’s wing. The news had called him a giant because it kept children in their beds and adults at their desks. Giants were fairy-tale. The truth of him was worse, being not quite fairy, not quite tale.

The night the first video went viral, her granddaughter had texted at 3:12 a.m., a string of messages that didn’t quite form sentences. Mr. Winn had turned on the radio instead of the TV. She trusted the voices that kept company with storms. They said what they knew and left what they didn’t in the hush between weather and the farm report. A name, Bob. It was the demotic of terror, a nickname for a thunderhead. Bob had come from nowhere and everywhere, a man large enough to bend streetlights into bows, a figure in a too-long coat, a sound like a truck idling. He taunted women, the announcer said, no singsong lilt to the words, just a flat line of information. He painted them black—painted their coats, their hair, their shoes, the sidewalk beneath their feet, not with tar or oil but with a black that seemed to insist on itself. A mark. A shaming. Or something more ritual and more stupid. The line between prank and assault was a line he scuffed until it looked like there was no line at all. The radio voice went soft the way people do when they tell you your lab results aren’t what they hoped. The police had a grainy still. Anonymous tips clogged the hotline. Copycats had already begun, across a city nine hours ahead, across a campus three in the other direction. The math of fear is always exponential. One becomes two becomes eight’s echo.

“Mr.,” called Indira from the hall, knocking with the bent knuckle she used when she brought soup. “You shouldn’t stand in drafts.” “Then the drafts shouldn’t stand where I’m standing,” Winn said, but she stepped back anyway, smile tucked in. Indira’s face was lit with phone-light. “He’s down there,” Indira said, pointing like that would help, like Winn didn’t have eyes of her own. “He won’t come up,” Winn said. “Monsters like slopes.” “Is he a monster?” Indira asked, and Winn let the question be a saucer she put down on the table without answering. They stood, two women in a kitchen that still smelled faintly of last week’s onions. The refrigerator made the sound of a distant shore. “You can call someone,” Indira said. “Who would come?” Winn felt the old teacher rise in her throat, the tone she used to call a class back to itself. “They’ll come. They’re always late, and they always come.” “Do you think he knows we’re watching?” Indira whispered. “He wants the watching,” said Winn, and was surprised at the certainty in her own mouth.

The first time a copycat killed someone, it wasn’t on purpose, an anchor said later in a voice tuned to hush hysteria. It never is, the anchor added in tone if not in words, and someone had to go to the hospital for saying what she wasn’t allowed to. A young man in a hoodie had flung paint at a woman jogging at dusk along a seawall. She stumbled into traffic. A truck’s driver didn’t see. The numbers changed. They made the crawl at the bottom of every screen into a thicker rope. This is how it works, Mr. Winn thought, not for the first time. We name it. We feed it. It grows. In a grainy clip from Hamburg you could hear a man laughing: “We’re painting the night,” and a chorus of hoots, a laughter that sounded like coughs. In Lagos a woman sat on a stoop and wiped at her blackened hands with a dishcloth, her mouth a hard, white line, the camera recipient of her controlled fury. In Seoul a subway car stood with its doors open while maintenance crews swabbed at streaks that had seeped into the plexiglass like bruises remembering fists. The words were different because languages are, but the rhythm was the same. This was not just him anymore. This was a contagion that did not need a carrier now that the idea itself had a skeleton. Deaths rose in the way calculators do when your finger holds down a button too long.

Mr. Winn took out a notebook with a marbled cover and a list began without her permission. It was always like that. Lists were a reflex, a scratching itch. She wrote dates, times, locations, details that felt useful because they were small. “He hums,” she wrote. “No gasoline smell. No brush marks when he moves away.” She wrote: “He does not run. He is never earlier than the last bus. He looks up.” She had a friend on the force, or had had, years ago, a young officer who’d taken her class twice because math was a beast he wanted to domesticate. He was a detective now and wore his exhaustion like a well-cut suit. She still had his card, the printed number as irrelevant as a street address to a person who preferred bridges. She dialed him anyway. “Côté,” he said, his voice the same as always, a tree trunk. “It’s me,” she said, and waited for him to catch up. He did. “Mr. Winn,” he said, warmth tucked under the formalities. “I’ve got nothing to give you,” he began, and she cut him off. “I’m not asking for secrets,” she said. “I’m asking for your patience.” “That I have,” he said, and she could hear him set something down on a desk, the wafer of a coffee cup finding a ring. “He’s out there,” she said. “He’s everywhere,” Côté answered. “Tell your people to stay inside,” she told him, and then laughed because who were her people anymore? “We’ll increase patrols,” he said instead of the truth, and in the pause they both thought the same thought: late, late, late.

If the giant had a name before the feeds named him Bob, if he had a mother who held his wrist as they crossed the street and told him not to touch the wet paint on the porch railing, if he had a neighbor who took in his mail when he went away once, none of it mattered now. Now he was a rumor that wore boots. He thought in alternating currents. He walked with a patience learned from watching a river wreck its banks. He did not dream. Or if he did, the dreams were what the world called waking. His hatred was not personal; he would have told you that if you had asked him and stayed long enough to endure the answer. “It’s pattern,” he would have said, “it’s the smallness of your lights,” but what he meant was thrumming in his wrists, a music like a headache. Women turned the world. Women insisted on being suns. It offended him and that offense was his oxygen. He found a joy in making a gloss of the faces that would not shine for him, as though he could put night back where day had dared to nest. He had no slogans. He found them in the mouths of others, in the comments section that floated him like a sea supports a corpse. He didn’t need to be smart. He needed to be seen. He was very, very good at being seen.

For a time, after her husband died, Mr. Winn had logged in to rooms filled with strangers who remembered things. She found homes in the places where the records of old roads lived, in the corners of the internet where aerial photographs of towns in 1953 meant something to someone besides a city planner. She had a handle, m.r.w., and a reputation for accuracy. It turned out that the people who hunted lost deeds and collected abandoned maps were the same people who saw patterns before the police framed them. They had threads. They had spreadsheets that looked like quilts. “It’s a copycat cascade,” someone wrote. “Normalcy bias is broken, so they’ll try anything that looks like story,” wrote another, and Mr. Winn loved her for saying so. A person with a name that wasn’t quite a name—arkady—sent her a file. She had to pick it up like the old days, with more caution than necessary. It was a clip of a garage where someone had recorded a shadow as it went by. Not much. Lucid noise. But in the audio, under the thrum of a refrigerator, you could hear a low voice say, “Paint is confession.” She played it again and again until the phrase lost meaning and turned to rhythm. Paint is confession. Confession to whom? The last time she had confessed anything it had been to her daughter on a bench by the river: I cannot be the woman you need me to be. She had meant patience. She had meant stamina. She had meant: I am old. Her daughter had nodded and held her hand as though Mr. Winn were the child and not the other way around. It had been a good day.

When the night market came back to Kitchener after its winter break, the organizers posted signs promising extra security and foolishness at a minimum. The night smelled like sugar and charcoal. Mr. Winn went because she refused not to. She moved through the crowd like a ship through reeds, the cane making a percussive rhythm that kept her honest. Wachowski’s dumpling cart had a line like a pilgrim trail. A girl at a stall called CandleLit sold jars the size of fists with wicks braided like sailors’ knots. At the entrance, a police van idled, officers standing in pairs with the stiffness of people who want to be anywhere else. Mr. Winn found a bench made of three planks and a history of splinters. She let the crowd move around her. She had learned to be still. Around her, phones pointed at food and faces. The paint was obvious when it came because it did not catch the light. The giant did. He moved at the edge first, the way a storm tries out its voice before it takes to the center. A woman laughed too loudly at something in the next stall and the laughter cracked. He didn’t go for her. He reached for the canvas of a mural someone had commissioned for the event, a wash of bright oranges and blues, a woman’s face composed of flowers, a celebration, and with one calm swipe he salted it with night. The crowd hissed like a continent of kettles. He turned and the black he’d made seemed to expand, a wet blot on the eye.

“You don’t have a right to that,” Mr. Winn said, not sure whether she was talking to the art or the air around it. He heard her. Of course he heard her. He found her with an ease she found obscene, a snap of attention like a lighthouse beam falling square on a window that thought itself a secret. He smiled. He wasn’t young, but he wasn’t old. His face was the kind you forgot immediately while remembering forever the idea of it. He tipped his head at her, as if she’d told a joke that he liked. “You like rules,” he said. “I like boundaries,” she said. “They keep the wrong people out.” He raised the brush. He didn’t bring it close. He tapped it against his shoulder in a bored little rhythm. The black did not splatter. This was the thing that broke her heart more than anything: the black obeyed him. “You think names will help you,” he said. “They always have,” she said. He waited as if for a better answer and when none came, he turned away and trailed his brush along the ground in a line that the children would step over tomorrow as though it were the border between lands on a map.

Afterwards, in the wash of siren colors and the sizzle of indignation, people gave her credit she hadn’t earned. “You stood up to him,” said a young woman with a shaved head and a tattoo of a sparrow on her wrist. “I’m very tired,” said Mr. Winn, and meant it. Côté found her near the exit, his tie loosened, his face a cantilever of worry. “You shouldn’t have engaged,” he told her, the way a teacher tells a kid to keep hands flat on the desk. “He listens,” she said. “He listens to hear where the fear is,” Côté answered. “Then we’ll whisper,” she said. “Don’t make jokes,” he told her and then seemed to hear himself and smiled despite where they were. “We can’t get ahead of him,” he said, low. “We’re always reading his footprints.” “Because you keep pretending he’s singular,” she said. “He’s not one. He’s many, and he’s a story.” “We can’t arrest a story,” he said. “You can if it has a body,” she said, and the look he gave her was something like belief and something like grief. He wrote his new number on the back of her hand like anyone’s teenage friend and told her to call only if it mattered. “It always matters,” she said, and he ran a hand over his hair and didn’t answer.

The market closed a half hour early without calling it that. Everywhere, the faces of women had a new tightness to the mouth, a new swivel to the head on the neck. If you’d been dropped into that crowd from space you would have said: there are hawks above. News came in even before she got home. A hospital in Newark on lockdown. In Jaipur someone with a bucket and a bandanna had been chased across a roof and had fallen wrong. A vigil in Prague, candles under a statue that wore a shawl of soot. The counts became their own tally marks. The lines on the graphs found a steeper angle as though something had leaned its weight against them. Someone on Stoneflower posted a screenshot of the growth curve with the caption, “This is not natural” and Arkady answered, “Nothing viral needs to be natural once it’s taken root in minds.” Mr. Winn clicked and clicked until the numbers blurred and what remained was the thudding truth: this would get worse before worse became a measure too small to hold it.

In the morning, a thin envelope slid under her door. It had a stamp from a town she knew from the taste of its name. Bloom. A postmark like a scar. She sat. She was, if she was honest, a person who believed in omens if they came in the shape of the mail. The note inside had been typed on a machine that refused to give itself to the century. The letters had inconsistent ink, as though some of them had been loved more than others. Win, it read, which put a crack in her heart. Only three people wrote her that, and two of them were dead. The third was Lenka, who had left years ago for a prairie sky and never looked back. The note was four sentences. His paint isn’t paint. It’s the dark of a thing that eats light. Shadows can’t swim. Find where the river is deeper than he thinks. Then, in a smaller script, as though shameful: It will like me less for telling you. She pressed the paper to her mouth as if she could taste the place it had been written. Shadows can’t swim. Ridiculous. Useful. Most truths that mattered started as a thing you could only say slant.

She spent the day walking the city with the map of it superimposed on her brain like the overlay of a blue diagram. The river bent and split and gathered itself again. Bridges had personalities; some invited, some dared. At the iron footbridge by the old mill, graffiti had been layered so many times you could feel the strata with your fingertips, noble sediment of bored summers. She paused midspan and looked down into water that did not carry a perfect reflection but a rubbed-out version. Her cane leaned against the railing while her free hand held a thermos that had once belonged to her husband, a dent near the cap where the world had tried to whack it into another shape. “He wants a stage,” she told the wind. “He wants a chorus and he wants it to sing his tune.” She thought about the last bus stop before the bend, about the way the streetlights failed to reach the riverbank because budget was always what you thought you could hide beneath a word like prudence. It would have to be soon. The city could not keep holding its breath.

That night she didn’t sleep so much as catalog horizontal hours. She had a dream about a classroom with no desks, the students standing, faces upturned like sunflowers, only their centers were black and the petals dull. She woke with a sentence in her mouth: To solve a problem, you have to believe a solution exists. It wasn’t hers. It belonged to the textbooks she had flung away in disgust years ago. But a bad sentence can hold a good crumb, and she combed it. Believe a solution exists. Not a cure. Not a hero. A way. She found her boots. She found the key to the basement where the building’s old laundry sink held water cool as forgiveness. She filled two bottles and swung them into a bag. She put on the coat that didn’t mind rain. She wrote a note to Indira in case, because this is what you do when you leave the possibility of not returning. Hello I am taking a foolish walk. If I do not return, do not let them say I went quietly. She stuck it to the fridge magnet shaped like a pear.

The streets at midnight were a quieter kind of busy. A cat preluded her down the block and then ducked into a hedge as though embarrassed by its own company. A man in a parka walked a dog whose leash had LEDs that looked like a child’s bracelet. The river spoke in its many voices. Ahead, the bus stop kept its vigil. There was no bus scheduled now, but buses have their own rules about crisis, and she’d seen them roll up empty just to change the air. He would come. He had learned the schedule of their forgetting. Her cane struck sparks from the sidewalk in her mind, though it did no such thing in actual. She chose the far side of the shelter and stood where the bank sloped toward the water’s shoulder. She was not, she scolded herself, a brave woman. She was simply the one who had gone. That will have to do, she told the imaginary teacher who lived in her sternum. Across the river, a light went on in a house and then off again, the occupant making a decision that was none of her business.

She heard him before she saw him. Not footsteps. A shift in the night’s voltage. The kind of quiet that isn’t empty but taut. The black came with him. It was as if he had a shadow that had recruited other shadows and all of them waited for his signal to advance. He was tall as a story told by a liar. He stopped beside the shelter and considered the ad for a thrill show in some city that wore its noise like a crown. He set down his bucket. The black did not slosh. “You again,” he said without turning. “Me,” she said, and the sound was so inadequate she added, “I taught math,” as if competence could be an armor anyone would honor. He faced her then, and the brush lifted on its own as though a man had attached to it merely for show. “You don’t get to write the world,” he told her, and she didn’t answer because it seemed foolish to disagree about something like that. “You get to scribble,” he allowed. “You get to flick your little lights at each other and call it love.” “You came from somewhere,” she said, and surprised herself with the tear that rose and did not fall. He looked past her as if he had a more interesting student than this one. “Everything comes from somewhere,” he said. “So what.” He took a step toward her.

“Shadows can’t swim,” she said, softly, like a prayer you don’t admit to. He stopped. It was not the words; it was the posture of words. “Someone told you a joke,” he said. “It isn’t a bad one.” “It isn’t a joke,” she said. “And if it is, I’ve chosen to laugh at you and not with you.” “Do you think you can insult a tide?” he asked, and there was something close to admiration in it. “I know tides fail,” she said. “They fail to drown us every time.” He took another step. The slope behind her waited, a darker dark. Her hands were steady. She thought of the letters in Lenka’s note, some of them bold with habit. She thought of the little girl at the market with the sparrow tattoo who had said you stood up to him and had meant I wish I were you and had been wrong. “You don’t have to do this,” she told him, lying. “I do,” he said, and for the first time there was something in his voice like honesty. “I truly do.” The brush lifted, something in the air tense as the skin of milk in a warmed pot.

She stepped back. The bank was steeper than it looked, the grasses slick with the day’s leftover damp. The river took her ankle and then her knee. Cold wrote itself around her bones. She did not yell. He leaned forward, amused, but did not offer a hand. The dark around him thickened as if it took a breath. “Careful,” he said, mock concern a chord he could play well. She took another step back because she had committed to this, because retreat had become a kind of advance. The night rearranged itself in that moment into a diagram she could read. She felt the water pulling and the mud letting go. She smelled the city and the river and the paint that was not paint. The brush he held trembled, just slightly, as though it too had a pulse. He lifted it and extended it toward her, curious suddenly to see if the river would take the color the way walls did, if water could be made to admit his mark. He reached. She reached. His shadow tilled itself forward as a field does when a wind scythes it. And then—

Chapter 2

And then the river did the oldest trick it knew, which was to be many things at once. It was a mirror smeared by thumbprints and a beast with a cold tongue and a ledger that remembered what fell into it. The tip of his brush hovered like a surgeon’s scalpel and when the black that was not paint reached for the water, the water reached back in a way that was not reach at all but refusal. The smear he teased toward her slid off the bristles as if embarrassed to be seen and went to lie on the surface with the smugness of oil until the current tugged and the thing that ate light discovered that the feast was not for it. It puckered. It shivered like skin under a voltage. It tried, with the insistence of a stubborn child, to remain itself and could not. What had always obeyed him made a sound that was not a sound but a feeling in her teeth and the smear tore, not into droplets but into absences that collapsed under their own lack and fell through.

He flinched for the first time since she’d seen him, a minute pull at the corner of his mouth as if a fish had tugged a hook buried there. His shadow did a strange mathematics, thinning away from the river’s edge as if the slope were a proof it had failed. He shifted his weight, surprised, and the bucket cocked against his shin. She did what she had carried water through ninety minutes of doubt to do. She dragged the bag up from the wet against her hip, worked the cap with fingers that had taught endless children to turn stubborn screw-tops, and flung a bright rope of water across the low air between them. It arced, so small a gesture against so much night, and struck the bristles first. The brush convulsed like a living thing. The black on it did not splash; it retreated, trying to knit itself back into the ferrule and finding no seam that would hold. The little runnels that made a face of him a moment ago—cheekbone shadow, socket, the hint of a jaw—lost their conviction.

He snarled without voice, the throat working as though he’d swallowed a burr. He reached for her with the empty hand, not for help but for the satisfaction of forward motion, and his boot bit into the grass and then into the mud that had planned this. She had planned this too; she took another back-step because sometimes the trap is the willingness to stumble. The river made a sound at her knee that, if you had no poetry, you would call glug and if you had too much, you would call invitation. She uncapped the second bottle, her hands remembering the thermos from her husband’s factory nights, the tin taste and the winter steam, and she poured again. This time she went for the line where his darkness lay on the ground like fabric. The water, which was only water and did not know itself as weapon or mercy, ran into the black and the black thinned again like a rumor encountering fact.

He tried to draw the brush back and found that he could not do it clean. Fibers clung, or not fibers, whatever the shadow’s equivalent of hair might be, tugging like weed-roots. For a heartbeat he was a boy in a backyard with a too-strong kite tugging at him, the wind not physics but will. He stepped after it out of habit and the bank, with the impartiality of a ledger, subtracted him a degree of balance. The bucket went over. It did not pour; it leaned and the dark inside of it tried to decide whether to answer gravity like a liquid or like a position held by a soldier. In the indecision the river found opportunity. It pulled, which is to say it recited its catechism of down, and the lip of the bucket kissed the surface and the thing in the bucket made a noise like a string snapped back on a cello and then lost shape.

To call what happened next panic would be to reduce the moment to a nervous system. He did not flail. He did something worse, which was to calculate and lose. His hand tightened on the brush, the way a person grips a talisman that has never once warranted such faith. The black that had always loved him, if love is obedience, wavered as his shadow did, its edges feathering where the river breathed. He had never looked young to her and he did not now, but the set of his shoulders admitted confusion in the language of muscle. He stepped away from the water and discovered that away had contracted. The strip of grass that had been his dry stage was a scarf, a belt, something narrow that had lost pretension to breadth. His laugh, when it came, had no shape to it. It was the laugh of a man in an elevator that has stopped between floors, hands empty, the plan a mist.

She was cold to the hip now and her joints were giving her their old lecture, but she’d made promises to herself in the hours the dream with the sunflower faces had eaten. She stayed. She did again the small thing that the large thing disliked. She sloshed what remained along the toe-space of him, a line not at his body but at the insistence outside his body that dressed him. The sound it made didn’t repeat; it never repeated. This time it was almost relief, like a sighed yes in a sleeping room. Shadows can’t swim, Lenka had typed, and here was the footnote: they could drown or they could be rinsed away or they could snap back hard and cut. When a piece of his dark tore free and fell into the river, it made a hole where the night should have been and then the hole filled with an ordinary mid-March black. She watched the absence remembering itself into one more stripe of water.

He did not run. He shed. He let go of the brush all at once and when it hit the bank it did the worst possible thing, which was nothing. It lay like a stick. It had become a stick. Something in him swarmed, the way hornets braid when their home is kicked. He reached for the bucket and thought better of it, for the first time honoring the river. He took a step back and the knife of mud on his boot tried to cut a second step from the bank and could not. The slim humiliation of it was visible even in the dark. He looked at her as if she had relieved him of a coat and then refused to give it back, as if she had revealed an indecency. “Small lights,” he said, but the words had no doctrine in them; they were rote. He tugged at the hem of his too-long coat as if to arrange a dignity that would travel and then walked the slow backward line he walked when he was on a stage he had not chosen.

Mr. Winn stood still until the cold worked its way through the brave and down to the practical. Her left foot was a complaint she could not ignore and the river, which respected no plan but its own, lifted a little to see if her hip might want to be a rock. She came up out of the water fox-slow, all calculation about which leg deserved to be first, the cane in a loop of strap around her wrist saving itself for the moment it would be more friend than emblem. She watched him cross the sidewalk, his shadow shortened, pinned to his heels like a one-sentence apology. He left no heel-and-toe punctuation now, just the plain grammar of boots. The bucket stayed upended, the brush a stick, the black in the grass a kind of bruise that did not spread, the night adjusting to an absence it had not known it had arranged around a man.

The bus that pulled up then was one of the hybrids, a hummed contralto riding under its breath. The driver saw her and in the space between habit and policy threw the lever that made his bus lower its knee. He came down two steps and then paused, taking in the river, the toppled things, the woman sopping at the edge of what could only look like a bad idea come to teach a class in consequences. “You all right, ma’am?” he asked, which was what he had to ask to unlock any other sentence. “I will be,” she said, which was the only answer she could trust. There were two passengers. One of them cried quietly without any connection to this scene, the kind of tired we never legislate; one of them held a bag of groceries like a baby. The driver looked past her into the dark the way you look at a dog that might or might not come when you call its name. “You want a blanket?” he asked, and when she nodded he went into the belly of the bus and came back with a roll of orange wool that smelled—to her surprise—like clean sun.

By the time she got herself up the stairs in her building, leaving wet on each step the way a snail leaves a slick, she had made a new list in the recess where lists live. The headings were simple, the subpoints anything but. Water interrupts. Running water eats edges. The brush is not tool; it is permission. The bucket and the brush, when unaccompanied by him, revert to the world. He is bound to the thing or the thing is bound to him in the old way of stories and belts. She peeled off her wet pants in the kitchen, because it was nearer the radiator and because the kitchen had always been the bravest room in any place she’d lived, and wrapped herself in the orange bus blanket for twenty civilized minutes. Then she got up, because reward is not a plan, and put the stick-that-was-a-brush and the upended bucket into the galvanized basin in the basement. She did not touch them with naked hands. It was the sort of precaution best left unspoken if you wanted anyone to take your scientific habits seriously.

Côté arrived with the morning in his face, thread-tracks where sleep had been and left. He knocked three times and then two, the way people do when they’ve practiced their courtesy. When she opened the door, he did the count in his head you only see when someone who is stubborn has done a sensible thing, and he nodded as if to say: I choose not to lecture you because it would cost too much coin from a purse you don’t carry. “You look like someone who fell in a story,” he said, and she made the shape of a laugh. He went to the sink without asking because the years let you and took the kettle from the stove and refilled it and set it back as if tea were as tactical as everything else he had learned to do. She told him and he wrote nothing down because the words made enough of a pattern without ink. When she got to the part where the brush became a stick, he put a hand to his mouth, not to hide surprise but to keep it from running off.

They went down to the basement together as if it were a ritual, the kind where you go toward the thing to make it less holy. The basin sat like a font someone had scooped out of the wrong religion. The bucket leaned and didn’t drip. The stick lay across it with the boredom of a ruler on a desk. He reached and stopped and then reached again, because caution can topple into superstition and he had always been braver than that. His fingers went to the bucket’s lip the way a locksmith goes to a key, all respect. He accelerated the world with a small tilt. They both held breath. Nothing happened except the small chuff of air that lives under emptiness. “It’s not paint,” he said, making factual what had been atmospheric. “No,” she said. “Lenka writes as though we’re living in a folk catalogue. Running water, bridges, invitations refused. Shadows can’t swim.” “Lenka?” he asked, and she let him know what there was to tell without bending the light toward romance.

It should have been a relief and was only a shape that looked like one from a distance. He would increase patrols near the river and the markets; he would put a note on the overnight brief to ask that cruisers carry a case of bottled water meant for parched protestors and now repurposed for witchcraft. He would be laughed at by a man with teeth like polished cutlery, the laugh a thing with three syllables of contempt in it, and then later he would catch that same man undoing the top of a bottle and he would look at the ceiling and tell no one. “You’ll be careful,” he said, and they both let it sit on the table like a lily. “I will be old,” she said, which was not the same.

Stoneflower, which had only ever been a place for maps to find their friends, shifted its fire like any camp does when the wind misbehaves. When she typed her notes, her private was not very private because everyone who needed to know could smell when something had moved under the tent. Arkady came up from under her into the thread like a diver, leaving green trails of code and a word that no longer meant anything to younger mouths: careful. Someone in Reykjavík posted a clip, thirty seconds of a street where rain had come down and a bucket had not worked the way its carrier had hoped, which is to say the street had become crowded with the wrong kind of river and the man in the too-long coat had decided that a doorway was a better idea. Someone in Durban wrote in a clarity that cut the way good knives do: moving water is a boundary in many stories; we stop calling them stories when they are ours. They began, one of them, two of them, then eight with echo, to put blue icons next to their names, not ribbons because ribbons go hard with pride but drops, the shape so simple it tricks you into thinking it has no teeth.

In the building, Indira came with soup and expectation. “I saw the blanket,” she said, and Mr. Winn would later bless the universe for people who could make a syllable do that much work. They sat at the old table that had come with a man who could make what wood wants from only a knife and patience and they spoke the kind of sentences that live only between women with no desire to be applauded. They spoke about kettles and the refund the market would not give because it had spent it already and about how to put bottles near places where you might need them without becoming an advertisement for a war. Indira’s niece printed flyers that said Riverwater, a tidy list of places you can fill and an even tidier list of where not to, and a note in a font that made you want to listen: we will not hunt, we will only interrupt. Someone from the second floor added in pen because pens are how revolutions remember themselves: bring cups.

She slept then, not deeply, but usefully. In the anteroom of sleep she saw the brush twitch back to being a brush like a frog unhexing to frog and she woke hurting and smiled hurt, which had been a private sport of hers since the year her husband’s heart made its last, foolish noise. In the morning the graphs tried to north again and then plateaued, and the anchors’ voices held a border of baffled hope the way cake holds icing on a too-hot day. Copycats who were never more than paint and bile found they were easy to pick up by the scruff when girls with water pistols pinned them at fountain’s edge and sprayed and their shouts broke into adolescents’ squeals against their will. The big one, the one whose not-paint starved under river rules, moved away from the damp and into the parking structures where the air is always wrong. He no longer drew lines on the ground and asked children to hop them. He put his fingers on mirrors and left the kind of smear that makes you check your face for something you cannot see.

She went with Côté, one afternoon that pretended to be spring but was a liar, into a garage that had become a chapbook of attempts. The mirror of an elevator wore black around its frame like eyeshadow on a person who had slept in it. A line of compact cars had black hats. A last-year snowpile that had become sediment watched them from a corner with indifference. She had brought a thermos because she had learned to bring a thermos to everything, and when she unscrewed the cap the pour did something strange. It went slow where it should have gone quick. It veered like a drip finds a path along a ceiling. It made a new lace out of the black that had thought itself a stain and turned it into nothing more heroic than wet floor. The young officer at Côté’s elbow exhaled in a little hymn and then tried to put the air back in his mouth, embarrassed at having made that much emotion in front of veterans.

They made the city practice something it had never wished to be good at. Sprinklers were asked to stay up into the night. The water department, which had always thought of itself as the sibling who worked and never got invited to weddings, became the guest everyone wanted to sit beside. Hydrants were tested and their caps painted with humorous murals of fish wearing crowns because if you do not make a little joy of your tools you will grow to hate them. The night market issued its new rules in a voice grown soft with apology and stubbornness both. There would be water tents beside the tarot readers. There would be jugs beside the buses. There would be a child at a folding table with a sign that said free refills in writing that leaned to the left as if running downhill.

Nothing cured. He adapted. He learned the timings of sprinklers and chose hours when the water’s art had ended. He ordered an umbrella from a catalogue of amusing goths and when it arrived it blazed black that was simply black, not anything more interesting. He used it primly, which was the only way he could use anything. He went indoors more. He began to sit in the last pews of churches with the confidence of a man who has confused pew for throne, and when women walked past him he hummed his anti-music and let his dark make small taps that would have been kisses if he had been a person who believed in kisses. Mr. Winn stood in a vestibule one Sunday behind a rope of old ladies whose faith was a habit and watched his dark hesitate at a dish of holy water and then move around it with a courtesy that made her laugh in a way that made the usher give her a glance he had been saving since 1973.

At night she and Indira and four others who did not need a name met in the laundromat because the hum was protective and the light was honest. They rolled coins between their fingers and talked about schedules and about whether the children should be the ones to carry the bottles because they were fast or never the ones because they were those you are obliged to shield. They talked about whether to leak the phrase shadows can’t swim into the sweetpipe of the rumor machine or hold it under their tongues like a peppermint that lost its taste only slowly. Arkady wrote: secrets held too tight turn into teeth; give it away and it will be a song. Lenka wrote again and the postmark was a farm town with a name like a jar of jam and she had typed with even more inconsistency this time, the ink giving up on a couple of vowels. A river is not the only running thing, the note said. There is blood. There are crowds. There are the conveyer belts at the airport that we pretend are polite. She added in the small shame-hand: I am not joking and I am not pleased to be right.

Of the things Mr. Winn had taught, one returned like a native bird. You put numbers to your feelings so they don’t run away with you. A week into water, the calls edged down. The copycats lost interest when they found that women with Nerf guns and adult patience could humiliate them in the uncomplicated way that breaks a boy’s willingness to be brave for the wrong prize. The tally of deaths, which had become a rope dragged behind a boat with too many bodies on it, slackened. Someone put teal ribbons on an iron fence again and their flutter did not feel like an apology no one accepted. And yet the man who was not theorem and not myth had learned the lot numbers of fear. He moved to places where water would be needle and not sheet. He learned grocery aisles, the way the misters go on and off in produce. He learned gyms, the hour their showers fail the health inspection and close. He learned how to be drought.

One evening, Arkady wrote: come to the pool. Mr. Winn took the sentence into her kitchen and asked it to sit. The pool was a city thing, a rectangle with an echo, the place where summer’s children practice the small civilities of lane etiquette and winter’s elders remember that their bones used to be more than columns. She went, which is to say she let herself be driven by Indira, who had a hand on the wheel that kept time with a song no one else could hear. The lifeguard, a child with shoulders like intentions, closed the doors and pulled the blinds because if you are going to change anything you must make a theatre of it. Côté was there, which made a wrongness right, and two women who had been painted and who wore that fact like a pin that says I voted. Arkady sat at a table with a laptop and spoke as if she were presenting a plan for a picnic: he likes mirrors; he hates surfaces he cannot count on; he would like to make this water pretend not to be itself.

They made an experiment from the awkward grace of community. They put a small pane of plexi on a pole and drew a line of his black across it. They lowered it into the water while all the bodies in the room learned to flinch at the same time. The line smudged airlessly and then unmade itself, not dissolving, no chemistry anyone in a white coat would approve, only losing the arrogance that allowed it to be a substance. It took longer than at the river because stillness defers decisions. The painted women in the corner breathed like people who have relearned a word in a language they forgot they spoke. They did it again and this time lowered the brush, which she had not wanted to touch until this moment because touching is a confession when you have been telling yourself you are a mind. The brush trembled against the surface of the water as if remembering the night it had been unmade and refused and she loved it for being wood again.

The test did not give a cure; it gave a list. Running faster works better than waiting politely. Moving water is a hungrier mouth. Distance isn’t virtue; it is just distance. He, wherever he was that night, might have felt a tug in the hamstrings if that is the kind of story you allow yourself, the kind where the villain’s muscles know when his tools are misbehaving. Mr. Winn sat on the staging and put her feet into the shallow end and ate a piece of chocolate that had been in her pocket since October and tasted of lint and found it exquisite. Côté stood near the door and talked into his phone with the patience of a man explaining arithmetic to a budget. Arkady packed the laptop with the tenderness people reserve for instruments that have failed them and might yet surprise them. Indira leaned her head on Mr. Winn’s shoulder in a way that said: even warriors have necks.

“Paint is confession,” she told the quiet on their way home, because it had been waiting, wanting to be said not to a recording but to a road. If he were only paint, the confession would have been: I am lazy, I am mean, I am jubilant at my own power. If he was the dark of a thing that eats light, the confession might be: I am hungry and I mistook my hunger for a map. She did not forgive him. She did not make a speech about forgiveness in her head. She named the things she knew how to name. Buildings, streets, the crook in the river, the woman who sang on the porch three doors down in a voice that had never been paid. Her heart did its old skipping trick and then remembered itself and she blessed it for its learning.

He was not gone. He sat in a booth in a diner that still had the original tiles and watched a waitress brush crumbs into her palm and told himself a story about crumbs and women that would have made a smaller man blush. He watched the window, the way the snow-scar on the curb had turned to a gutter of water and none of it had come into the diner because some buildings have opinions and some doors honor them. He thought about the river and how it had spoken back to him and he felt, for the first time, the pressure of choosing. He could leave. He could go to a city that had paved its river into an act of memory. He could become rumor only and surrender the weight of boots. The comment sections would still float him. He could be borne.

But there was a bus stop by a hospital he hated for the way it let women emerge stronger than when they went in, as if brokenness were only an opinion. He thought of that glass, how he had once stroked it and made the ad below it choke on a kiss it had not invited. He stood and the diner’s bell on the door made a noise that had been someone’s idea of cheerful. He left his coffee half-drunk because leaving a thing uncompleted was his private sacrament. He walked in that measured way that made the air think twice and the women at the counter leaned toward each other the way birds do when hawks are above. Outside the snowmelt had its own plans. He did not alter his route for water; he did not yet believe in priests.

Mr. Winn watched the hospital stop from a distance that kept faith with both prudence and desire. She had a thermos because she would always have a thermos now like people have their keys. She had a girl from the eighth who had spent the summer interning at City and knew how to talk to a parking authority so they beam smoothed instead of roughing up. The glass of the shelter was new and therefore felt brave, and she admired it the way you admire a child winning the first time at anything. When he came, he came like weather called by a conductor. He did not look up at the cameras because he no longer cared about those eyes. He put his two fingers on the glass as if he were greeting it like an old friend. The black tried to come forward with him like a well-trained pet and then stopped with its nose up against the new film some municipal genius had spread with a roller at three that morning, a film that promised hydrophilicity in the kind of brochure that would not normally travel far from trade shows.

He pressed. He pulled back. The smear he made attempted to be a smear and met its litigant in the thin wet that the film called up from air almost by thought. It would not hold. The ad below, cheap and earnest, did not choke. It simply looked back through the wet at him with the stupid dignity of printed eyes. He let his hand fall. He hummed his un-melody. He turned his head because something had changed and you always turn your head toward change the way you turn toward a dropped tray in a restaurant. Two women step toward him not to attack and not to scold but to stand. They had badges, not police, not anything that will ever carry a gun, badges that said volunteer and a drop shape, and their bodies made a shadow on his shadow the way clouds make promises to fields. He chose not to move at all. He chose to own immobility as if it were skill.

He stared at the hospital doors and she stared at the bend in the river where it cleared its throat before it mazed through town. She did not look at him. She did not make herself a mirror. She lifted the thermos and poured water in a small curve along the lip of the shelter’s slab and the water went on doing, in this dry season of men’s making, what it had decided to do before men. The volunteer on the right told a joke about hydrants so quiet the other volunteer had to lean to hear it and they both smiled in a way that made the air less sure of itself. Mr. Winn took a new page in her marbled notebook when she got home and wrote on it with a linearity that would have made her younger self smirk. Stories require boundaries. Shadow requires surface. Water upsets both. He requires applause. We can practice silence. She wrote practice twice because everyone always forgets that the word is both noun and verb, both plan and doing.

That night the building’s roof collected the faintest of rains and the buckets placed there by superstitious women and one good-natured super made small sounds of satisfaction. The internet, which had never loved her, loved what she and Arkady did not claim to have invented and therefore could not be caught taking credit for. There were videos of children—yes, she had lost this argument—holding up mister bottles like talismans and spraying as if christening streets. There were aunties tying ribbons with the drop shape around spigots and hoses. There was a woman in Lagos who said in her calm camera voice: we do not purify him; we do not purify ourselves; we make him slip. There was a priest in a collar not yet yellowed who said: we always had this; we baptized and forgot how.

The next morning, the envelope on her door had no postmark at all. The letters had been glued in the way of a school project, cut from newspapers and from the edges of magazines that would be missed only by people who care about font. It said, in the flat poetry of threats: rivers dry. She held the card over the sink as if the sink would catch any extra ugliness and she laughed, because people who think themselves storms always forget that storms travel, that there are lakes, that there are pipes, that there are mouths and if they are all you have left you make a river of them too. She got her coat. She tucked the note into the old cookbook she never used because good measures are not always recipes. She went to the elevator and the black on the mirror there had been washed again into ordinary by some underpaid person’s deliberate kindness, and she blessed that person with the decency of anonymity. On the way down she practiced the sentence in her head that she would say to Côté. It was not: we are winning. It was: we are learning.

Across town, in a garage that took its smells from tires and metal and tired men, he stood with his palm pressed flat to a pillar and felt the vibration of a freight elevator he hadn’t known was there. He liked the feeling because it made him think he was in the world and not merely on it, but then he had always mistaken vibrations for invitation. He tried again the old trick of the brush and found it made nothing but black that wanted to be a stare and could only be blink. He straightened and the men at the workbench found themselves too careful with their wrenches. He picked up a rag someone had left and he carried it with him down the ramp and out into the late day, and if you had looked from far you would have said: a janitor on his way to the next mess. If you had looked closer you would have seen a man practicing an intimacy and failing. If you had looked closer still, you would have seen the place where the rag was dark remember ordinary dirt and dismiss anything grander.

He went to the river anyway because hunger will visit the house that has locked its doors and will sing under the window until someone cries uncle. He stood on the bank above the deep he had underestimated and wished with an intensity he had only ever lavished on women’s fear. He wished he could believe in something older than his wanting. The river said none of this out loud. It did not gloat like men who win. It went on with its list: stone, leaf, paper, light. It took the city’s talk about it and sluiced that too. It did not refuse him because it is not a person. It refused to be his. That was enough. He turned, and the print he left on the path was ordinary and then there was the smallest sound, a bead of water falling from a branch onto a dried leaf, and he flinched like a horse.

She sat at her window and let herself be an oak when she was only a woman. She put her hand flat on the glass the way you do when a cat insists on being on the wrong side of a door. Her granddaughter texted her a string of nonsense that resolved into the picture of the child’s hand held under a faucet, water pearling at the base of the thumb, a caption from a life Mr. Winn had not lived at that age: like armor. She wrote back a heart, the old boring emblem that is sometimes a good, quiet truth. She turned off the radio because the farm report had become a dirge in its insistence on the price of corn when she wanted the price of us. She said out loud, to the much-underrated saints of plumbing: keep time with me. Then she did the math on the back of an envelope again like a woman after war, dividing what we have by how many we are and discovering with astonishment what will do when we let it.

Chapter 4

They put the city on a diet of water at the same time they taught it to throw water like a punch and the contradiction sat on every kitchen counter in the form of a note from Public Works. Use less, it said, with the tone of a parent who has been kind for too long. Use smart, the same note added, as if smart could be folded into a faucet. Mr. Winn stood over her sink and did the arithmetic no one who writes those notices ever shows their work on. There were gallons whose destiny was a lawn. There were gallons that were already promised to teeth and tea and a thousand small cleanlinesses. There were gallons that, poured at a bus shelter at the right second, could interrupt a man who had mistaken attention for oxygen. She made a list of taps the city could loosen without killing its own: hydrants for six sharp minutes on the quarter hours when shifts changed, cooling misters that would be fed by the graywater that no one believed in until the word gray turned out to be a kind of moral help. She wrote to a councilor who liked to be the first to know and the reply came back with the pace of a person who peeks over the cubicle wall: come say that into a microphone so that I can be the one who thanks you for it.

Stoneflower thrummed not with panic but with project. Arkady posted a video of a fan fitted with a hoop of foil streamers that churned the light in a room until the shadow in it could not stand still long enough to call itself anything but weather. It was nothing like science and everything like it, in the way of kitchen experiments that become recipes because a thousand hands stir them exactly the same wrong way. Someone in Winnipeg replaced the tinsel with strips cut from Mylar blankets they handed out at races and found that moving reflection worked as well as moving water when it came to making darkness lose track of its own outline. The thread became a bazaar of improvised flows: bead curtains that shivered when doors opened, sheets pegged to clotheslines over sidewalks and flapped by box fans stolen from bedrooms, panels on rolling casters that pushed wind ahead of them the way children push enthusiasm. Arkady wrote in a lower font, because of course she did: it is not that we are trying to blind him; we are trying to keep him from finding a surface to be sure of.

He, who had built his church out of the small faiths of strangers’ faces, adapted with the stubborn purity of a man determined to be original in an era that had no use for originals. He moved away from places that glistened and into places with carpet. He discovered that the black of him could sit, complacent, on upholsteries where water was a threat to deposit rather than a promise to cleanse, and for a spell he haunted waiting rooms the way a bad smell does. He hummed his hurt-music and trailed fingers near the photographs of mountains that administrative assistants put on walls to say: look, we are not a machine, we have views. The volunteers learned to carry sprayers with diluted detergent and to ask receptionists for rags with a conspirator’s smile that made those women feel suddenly and correctly like the keepers of the city. He went to the hospital lobby once more, and the film—some clever soul’s hydrophilic darling—made him scowl because it was invisible and effective, the two things he hates.

The doctor at her heart clinic listened to Winnifred’s chest and frowned thoughtfully in that way medical school teaches you when the truth is: I would put you in a box if I could and take you home like a rare bread, just to keep listening. His stethoscope was cold. His hands were not. He said the word arrhythmia as if he were afraid he might bruise it. She said, “It’s been a companion,” and then surprised them both by naming it Teddy, which made him chuckle and made the nurse look down so that her face might not betray her pleasure. “Do not forget that even the best companions know when to go quiet,” the doctor said, which was his way of saying: rest when you can and don’t play at hero. Her granddaughter showed up that afternoon with a plastic tub of chopped fruit and a plan that consisted mostly of standing in the doorway and being eighteen in a way that air likes. They looked at photographs in an album that smelled of basements and of the kind of paper no one makes anymore. The girl traced faces with one finger as if those people were all in there still, moving.

It was Lenka’s second letter that pushed them to a place no city is ever truly prepared to be comfortable with. Conveyors, she had typed badly, and added a sketch of an airport walkway that had been cut from a magazine years ago and taped to a page in a way that said she’d been saving it for the day it became what it was not. Mr. Winn took it to Indira, who had a cousin on a union executive that still believed solidarity could be tasted. Côté reached for the lever that made official channels move; he did not pull it gracefully because nothing with that many pulleys can be stroked, but he pulled. The airport director met them with the face of a woman who had negotiated with weather and with pilots who thought they were weather and did not enjoy admitting that a small old woman with a cane had brought her something she could use. “Tell me the version that makes me look savvy in a memo,” the director said, which is to say she was ready.

You never see an airport quiet unless you are either very early or very wrong. The night they took it for themselves, the place hummed like an aquarium. Belts that spent their days shouldering luggage wore only light now and the squeak of bearings that would be greased in the morning by a man named for his grandfather. A custodian whose name was stitched in blue stood with his mop like a spear and blessed them with an expression he probably used when his team scored, if he ever went to games. Mr. Winn placed her hand on the moving walkway’s rubber edge and felt the minute inconsistent bumps that have no poetry until you need them and then they become the stanza you can recite by heart. Arkady activated the curtains, a shiver of water that was not theatrical enough to make toddlers clap and not brutal enough to make teenagers post, just enough to count as running in the right way. They put out cones in a pattern that would make a herd flow without making it feel herded, because Lenka’s note had told them: crowds have current when they choose to.

He came with his own weather. Of course he did. He had read the rumor the way a man reads his reflection in a window and declares himself handsome because the night allows it. He did not like airports because airports do not care what you like; they are rituals that swallow individuality and spit it back in the exact bag it arrived in. He walked with the disdain that says men in vests should move aside and they did, because vests do not pay them enough to argue with disdain. The brush had been replaced because sticks do not resurrect and there is always another brush in the town that sells Home Improvement to men who are looking for a version of fatherhood. He aimed it at the chrome panelling along the moving walkway, which had been polished by boredom into a mirror so complacent it did not expect to be asked to do any work. When the black met movement, when the bristles found that their certainty ran away from them a fraction of an inch each second without ever consenting to be a single surface, it did not hold. It scummed and slipped and made the sound of teeth lightly worrying glass without leaving a bite.

The belts ran not fast, because this city was not a city that ever truly rushed, but with a confidence that belonged to machines and to rivers both. Volunteers stepped onto the belt in twos the way a dance begins at a wedding when the DJ knows something about age. They moved along him without stopping and their bodies made a current that bent his shadow oddly, pulling it toward their ankles the way grass leans toward a storm. One woman’s purse brushed his coat and the small apology she gave out of habit was like a blessing he did not know how to receive. He reached for the chrome again and a curtain whispered between his hand and the panel, a mist that did what water does when it is asked politely to decide against the continuation of a mistake. His hum lost confidence. He tried concrete—always a good friend to him in the old days—and found that the film the contractor had laid overnight at the direction of a woman he had never learned the name of made concrete act less like a wall and more like the skin of a fish half out of water.

Mr. Winn stood where the belt spit people back into their own legs and she used the lip of her thermos cap the way you would use a thimble to stop blood: precise, unpanicked, repetitive. There was a part of her that grew impatient with the theater of it, not because the work was melodramatic—it was not—but because she had always hated spectacle and here was one of theirs even if it was quieter than he would have asked. Côté kept up a cheerful murmur into his radio that sounded to anyone who did not know him like a man trying to make a burger order more interesting, and to anyone who did like a string you use when you want to keep a kite from bolting. The belt lifted his dark in slices that did not want to be slices and carried them toward the end where a catchment waited, a trough that the maintenance crew had insisted on calling a fish ladder until the looks from the women in the room made them try again and land on the less romantic—and therefore more useful—term trap. The pieces fell in and made a sulk on the surface. The tiny pump there, the only part of this entire evening that had been expensive enough to make an invoice blush, sent the sulk through a baffle and the sulk forgot that it had ever been a plan.

He went for the crowd then, which he had never dared because crowds can become something else if you get the scale wrong. He pointed the brush into the tide of women and men and teenagers who had decided that evening that they would practice being a river, and he found that fabric does what mirrors do not: it forgives. The black clung where it landed but it didn’t stay like a thought you can never shake. It smeared into motion and the motion became its own argument. The volunteers wore clothes they had rehearsed in: slicker fabric, old acrylic sweaters that did not keep stains the way a mother keeps grudges, skirts with panels that caught air. A mister hissed where a ceiling tile had been levered out, and the water fell not in big humiliations but in thin, unspectacular lines that you could mistake for a leak if you wanted to. It was enough. His hum turned into what it might have been once before someone told him he was interesting: a habit.

He dropped the brush when it remembered its first job again, a little too dramatically, like a bad actor’s idea of surrender. The handle bounced on the belt and went skittering down it and three hands reached to pluck it aside before someone fell. He had an umbrella in his coat, which would have made him ridiculous if ridiculous were not often a glove that fits evil perfectly, and he yanked it open in an arc that pushed two people to their heels. The water somewhere described a curve, not dramatic, not even particularly pretty, and struck the umbrella’s skin with a tiny percussion that belonged to summer porches. The black on the umbrella sulked and ran toward the ribs and gathered there into the sort of little puddles that cannot be seen from far. He looked smaller. He always had, a geometry of confidence rather than of height, but this was new: the light in the room had learned him and it kept its opinion.

They did not catch him. If this were the kind of story where triumph feels like a parade, they would have. A manager with a badge in a clip on his belt would have stepped forward with cuffs and the crowd would have made that applause that tells everyone we are grateful not because we are safe but because we have remembered a rule. He found a seam in the event the way a mouse finds one in a sack of grain, and he went through it with a quickness that took years off him. He left his umbrella open and the janitor with the stitched name lifted it in both hands like a small overturned boat and carried it as if it might bite. The belts ran for another twenty minutes just because it felt good to let something we had asked to do a job keep doing it after the reason had wandered off. The maintenance crew took apart the trap with the tenderness of men who have been mocked for their bulk and know the truth about delicacy, and what they put in a bag to send to a lab looked like the lint that dryers spit out when whole families have been washing clothes all day.

Afterwards, the airport director sat on a bench with Mr. Winn and let her head fall back to look at the ceiling, which was dull and dimpled like the underbelly of a whale in photographs. “I hate that we did something smart,” she said, and then clarified, because she was an honest woman when allowed to be: “I hate that we had to.” Mr. Winn said nothing because it is not polite to tell a person: you are living the moment when you discover that competence is merely the beginning. Indira handed out cups because she had insisted on bringing them, because she had written Bring cups! in pen on a flyer and pens are for this. Arkady sat on the floor in a way that suggested her bones were jointed differently than other people’s and rubbed her eyes under her glasses with the heel of her hand like a person bargaining with a headache. Côté took a call he did not want and afterward he said to no one and everyone: he’ll try the dam or he’ll try the places where wheels never stop. “We cannot flood a bridge,” someone said, and Mr. Winn said, “Maybe we can.”

He went to the river that night because he had nowhere else to go that would speak to him without sarcasm. The water looked up at him with its usual attention span, which is to say it did not hold a grudge and it did not forget. He stared at the dam and thought as hard as he could, which was a kind of apology, a child’s offering of effort. He imagined a dozen ways to make a wound in it and his mind lapped at each the way a tongue laps at a sore tooth. A man came and stood twenty yards away and put a cigarette in his mouth and then did not light it. They shared the silence the way two dogs share the shade of a small tree: without making rules about it. He thought about leaving because men like him always think there is a city somewhere that will not make them work this hard for attention. He imagined deserts. He liked the word because it didn’t ask you to learn the trick of its spelling until too late and he appreciated any word that resented correction.

At home, Mr. Winn told her kitchen about conveyance because kitchens are where movement begins in a house, in pots, in kettles, in drawers that slide because someone cared enough to get the rails right. They had learned to run water through the evening and to make light misbehave. They had learned to be a crowd that did not become mob. She made a list that had no bullets because this was not war and yet had the smell of it. She wrote: belts, fans, lungs. She wrote: buses lower for old bones—ask the drivers to linger the way they do when the woman with a walker needs a second. She wrote: the dam is not an enemy; it is a rhythm that can be interrupted without revenge. She wrote: the story is a river too; stop feeding it names and the fish will have to learn to eat plants. Her hand hurt when she’d finished and she pressed the heel of it into her own palm and felt the pulse that had been Teddy’s and thought about what it means for an old body to return to a fight one last time and find it still knows every step.

Lenka came as lightly as a letter when she did, months late and exactly on time, and the knock she made on the door was the sort made by someone who has calculated the cost of being turned away and will still call it a bargain if it happens. She stood on the thresh and two women whose hair remembered different climates looked each other into the present. They did not hug because there are reunions that deserve patience, and because both of them had learned that any abruptness invites the body to do things it will later resent. They sat because sitting is a discipline. Lenka’s face had made decisions without asking her, which is what faces do when we turn our attention to the state of the world and away from mirrors. “Conveyors,” she said, and laughed until her eyes found water that had nothing to do with misters. “You always did take my homework too seriously,” Mr. Winn answered, and their tea was exactly the right temperature, as if a cue had been thrown from a booth.

The night market returned like a child who has learned a new word it can’t stop repeating, and the organizers threaded lines above the stalls that tugged bits of foil in breeze. The dumpling cart steamed its offerings like small fogs and young men in shirts with sleeves rolled carefully to the elbow leaned beside it trying to remember why they had decided this was handsome. The bus shelter at the edge had a different photograph in it now, a picture of a woman in a hard hat smiling not at the camera but at something to its left, as if she were getting a joke no one had told and it still amused her. He stood across the street and weighed the market with his eyes the way an angler weighs a stream, and then he did something that nearly hurt her more than the things he had loved to do. He turned away. He did not want to perform where the stage had learned him. He wanted a new audience, though he would never admit that the word he really meant was victim. The city felt the way you feel when you see a hawk change course; it means salvation for some small birds and it means later for others.

They practiced silence in a way that nearly felt religious if you did not bring God to it. The drop pins multiplied but they did not add glitter to themselves, which was a kind of discipline that impressed Mr. Winn. People filmed less; or if they filmed, they handed their footage to Stoneflower without posting, and the site accepted the work the way a river accepts a piece of bread thrown to it by a toddler who believes in ducks. The anchors learned a new tone—one that reported without rendering—and when a woman in a newsroom slipped and said his name, her cohost touched her forearm lightly to say: remember, we have learned not to feed the river with that. The police, who had been forced by their funding and by their pride into pretending that water curtains were not part of law, began to carry hose couplers with the same absentminded ease with which they had always carried pens. In the laundromat, they pinned a new schedule near the coin machine, not of washing cycles but of shifts for the misters near the university tunnel, and the sound of quarters dropping into the slot had never been so companionable.

He went inland in his mind. He stood in a warehouse where boxes moved on belts he could not see the ends of and thought about what it would be like to make those belts hate themselves. He imagined painting the packages not with black but with the habit of hesitation. He lifted the brush and he drew a line on the metal lip of a chute and for a split second the line pretended it had a future. Then the chute shook the way a throat does when laughter will not be held and the line fractured, ran, and became a question that did not want his answer. He put the brush to the floor and felt ridiculous and did not like the feeling and did it again in spite of himself because sometimes practice is just cruelty that cannot climb. Mr. Winn dreamed of rivers whose names she had known when she was young and studying geography not because she believed in empire but because she understood that if you are going to fight anything you ought to know its shape.
