He pretended to be amused by the bus blanket still on the back of the chair and then failed to pretend, which made him more beautiful than he had ever been. He told a story about his mother and rain. It was almost nothing, and therefore it was the only thing that helped. She had set a coffee tin outside the back door during drought weeks and when rain’s first coins sounded on the tin she had called all her sons and made them listen on purpose. “This is what mercy sounds like,” she had said to boys who had deserved better than that one lesson and were fortunate to have received it nevertheless.

The museum that had survived a century by calling its halls rotation and letting the students rearrange its placards invited the city to an exhibit about water with a title that was too clever by half. He could not resist grand old rooms where whispers behave, where the hush has wood behind it and the floors remember being trees. He came with his hum like a mosquito in woodwork and drifted through dioramas where women in aprons pumped plastic handles and men in hats pointed at the river as if only fingers could make it obey. The volunteers had come in their niceness and their refusal to be fooled, and in the bag of one of them lay a sprayer that had been labeled with tape and marker stop for no reason except an old darkroom pun that felt like a cousin to an exorcism. He reached for the display case that held blueprints of the dam, his brush poised to take credit for a thing other men had built. The humidity in the room, managed by machines that had nothing to do with him and everything to do with the swell and shrink of old paper, took his not-paint from the bristles and made it forget, elegantly. It beaded at the joins. It sulked in the seams. The volunteer breathed across it and then sprayed the tiniest of veils, and someone at the far side of the room, a stranger with an ordinary face, began to explain in a quiet voice the difference between preservation and worship and the black left the case because it could not argue with sentences that had that much practice.

The nights went black not because the stars insisted but because the grid had an opinion about heat no one had thought to ask. The blackout did what blackouts do: made you hear your own appliances grieving their momentary deaths and made you slow your hands until you found every switch by the intimacy of familiarity. In the apartments with their single windows and in the shelters with their breath, people found again the companionship of candles and the ridiculousness of their danger. He liked the power’s absence; he believed it vested him. He stepped into a stairwell at a parking structure and found that stairs generate their own wind when a dozen people move with purpose and forget to pretend they are alone. Foil taped to the landing strings each floor into a small night sky, and the moon, if it had bothered to come, would have been humiliated by how much light it failed to provide. The volunteers had rehearsed rehearsals. They had strings of those cheap LED lights that taste your batteries and won’t let you forget it, and they wore them low, ankle-height, their glow making a river at foot level where his eyes did not want to go. He had brought a flashlight of his own, a fat thing that missionaries used to hand out to children in far away places, and he clicked it on and the light did not love him because light is not obedient when reflected multiplied into a forest of foil. He backed away from the stair’s updraft and tried the elevator and met a sign taped to the door with the good blue painter’s tape—out, honest as breath—and turned to find not a single lens raised in his direction. Indifference stung him better than water ever had.

There was, one afternoon, a scuffle of the stupid kind that tests a plan. A boy in a sloppy bandanna and exaggerated boots tried to paint the mirror of a nail salon because he had read somewhere that women keep secrets in mirrors and had misunderstood both women and secrets. He found on his first swipe that the black did not stay. The woman with the towel around her shoulders—her hair a bright wet banner that said she had chosen color over weather—reached without ceremony for the bottle she used to spray her plants. She wrote the boy’s face into a water and the boy yelped not out of pain but out of humiliation and she did not prolong it because women have better things to do. The copycat ran, the door chimed in its idiot way, and everyone went back to their stories, and in the lore of a city that learns by repetition and not by decree, the nail salon became a nice paragraph.

“Your granddaughter wants to take your class,” Indira said, always more dangerous than a knock, and Mr. Winn had to sit with the sentence because class is a word that implies desks and chalk and edges that deserve roll call. “What does she want to learn,” she asked, startled that her mouth had used the present tense as if she were an institution. “Counting,” Indira said, as if that were an immense act of optimism. They sat with it and did not make it grand. The girl came on a Thursday with a notebook that had been bought with hope, and they put columns on paper again, not the kind that folks with power protect with money, the kind that protect the mind with occupation. What do we do when the water fails us, the header asked, and they put under it things that were not water and a few that were but in different clothes: fans, breath, foil ribbons that made the air larky, a habit of moving slowly enough that a hallway’s draft could be courted. In the next column they wrote what we do for the water that does not fail us, and then they named faucets with addresses, hoses coiled near stairs, buckets set under roof corners for when the gutters sulked. The girl made a third column that neither of them had asked for: who to tell. She listed names and places not to call the press or the police but the people who sweep the stoops and the woman at the pool and the maintenance man whose shirt had a stitched name and a pride that did not wear badly.

He tried new edges because men such as he always mistake novelty for strategy. The old cinema reopened on a bet with bankruptcy and goodwill and he could not resist its lobby’s cracked tile and the posters that offered women from other decades to this one’s eyes like gifts. He stood under the chandelier, a cheap thing that had learned to pretend it was crystal, and he raised his brush toward a still life of faces set to kiss in a world where nothing went wrong for long. The manager, a young person who wore a ring in their lip like an punctuation mark that meant their own rules, walked up beside him and breathed with a small disdain. The air moved lightly in the lobby because someone had put a fan behind the candy counter where the popcorn machine told its creation myth, and the breeze insisted with a politeness that unstitched the trick he was about to perform. The brush trembled the way it had as a stick in the dirt by the river. He found himself using his mouth. “You think wind is all it takes,” he said to the manager, and the manager said, “Actually, we think organics, mechanicals, and social practice in a careful braid is what it takes,” and then smiled because they had been waiting all evening to say something that nutritious to someone who would not value it, and had said it anyway.

The drought pinched and the basil on the roof looked at the sun with an expression that could only be read as aside, and Mr. Winn and Indira took to carrying water up the stairs in a way that made them laugh at themselves and at gravity. They put broken tiles under the soil to keep it honest and wrote a note for the other gardeners that said please share the responsibility of thirst. A pigeon that had a sense of humor and no interest in permission came to study the tub and left its contribution on the edge, and they shrugged and thanked it because a city has its own nitrogen cycle. On a night when the smoke parted to let the moon sit closer than usual, the basil flowered, which meant it had decided to spend its remaining days on beauty and not on eating, and Mr. Winn clipped the tops and made a small pile of white and purple stars and thought about seeds as a kind of plan written in patient time.

In letters that leaned worse now because the typing ribbon in the secondhand shop had given up on its vocation, Lenka wrote about lungs. She had read papers in which words had been set badly to graphs and she had come away with only this worth bringing: breathe when it is hard as if the body is a bellows that has forgotten how to make a flame. Arkady copied the sentence to Stoneflower without attributing it because sometimes anonymity is its own kindness. The Hush Walk that week had a segment of instruction where people stood like foolish reeds and practiced breathing across their own knuckles, then across a square of plexi someone had found behind an art classroom, then toward each other’s shoulders in the careful, permissioned intimacy that you only practice during changed times. The breathing made the city feel like a set of lungs that had decided to make a choir, and in a corner of a video someone had filmed that nobody would post they caught him noticing the ridiculousness and not liking the way it made him feel outdated.

He broke one rule he had kept: he spoke to a camera. It was on purpose and yet not, because he had mentored himself into believing that attention would come if he called it by name and he did not measure until too late the cost of saying syllables into a lens. He stood in the park at noon and faced a woman who had set her phone on a rail because hands are needed for other things, and he said, “You are all so busy.” He said it the way a man says a thing at the end of a bar when he has just learned that people have lives without him. She did not look up. The phone kept its dignity. A child on a scooter counts for noise. The hydrophilic film on the transit map nearby shone like nothing special. He waited for his sentence to begin to do its work and when it did not he looked like somebody whose dogs would not come when called and he let his shoulders sag into a posture he had always told himself he had no need of. The woman on the bench returned to her book exactly because it had not asked anything of her, and he felt the smallest scrape of boredom’s knife on the underside of his appetite.

There was a night when the grid held but the pumps in three buildings did not. The water did not come up. Elevators will tell you that news with their petulant bells, but pipes tell it with a quiet that can be mistaken for peace. Indira knocked on doors because someone had to, and Mr. Winn went floor to floor with a list and a pitcher and the stubbornness of an old woman who knew ten thousand stairs already and had no fear left to spend on three hundred more. Côté arrived with a case of bottles he had told his lieutenant were for a softball game that would never be played, and together they made a river rise inside a hallway. No miracle attended. Feet hurt. The pitcher slopped. A child who could not sleep watched them from the open mouth of an apartment as if the grown-ups had finally put on the show the child had dreamed of when younger. At the end of the hall a woman stepped carefully over the foolishness of a black line two nights old and Mr. Winn poured a little of her ration along the lip of it without ceremony. It lifted away from the floor like a slug forced to consider it is not the only creature to own slime.

He tried the wrong kind of river and it startled him. At the roller rink that had been resurrected through a series of prayers printed on grant applications and the bone-will of a woman in neon laces, the floor made everyone move in circles that were not quite circles. He came in with his brush and stood by the edge and considered the physics of centrifugal mean, which had never done him any favor. When he drew his line, the skaters parted around it without touching it because bodies learn spatial negotiation early when wheels are involved, and then they breathed—it was that now, too—and the line went thin and thinner, and a boy in a helmet too large for his head shifted to avoid a girl with a braid longer than nobody’s business, and their draft made a weather he had not planned on. He licked his lip and found that he had tasted dust, not power. He left before his knees betrayed him and the DJ, an auntie with a taste for seventies basslines, let the music rise not because anyone had won but because the song needed to arrive at its chorus.

There were arguments in the laundromat because nowhere is pure. Someone said it was not their job to keep misters going in this economy. Someone else said that the drops were getting precious in a way that made them itchy. Arkady, arms full of fan blades and wires and the long patience that hides itself under competence, said, “Then we stop, and we see,” and the room recoiled because when you love a ritual you forget sometimes that you can put it down. They stopped for an hour in the university tunnel, an hour where students moved through the air without bead curtains clicking small songs against their shoulders, and he was with his hunger on the stairs when the hour began. He felt a thrill like he had not felt since before the river took him for the first time. He put his hand to the wall. He made his smear. The air was still because they had asked it to be. It did not last on the wall long enough for a story. Students moving have a current even without charms, and their bags made eddies and their breath made a tide, and in eight minutes the smear had become a lesson without teacher. When the hour ended, the thread on Stoneflower that had wanted to be angry chose instead to be smug in the way that helps nothing and hurts nobody, and the argument folded itself and slotted back where it had come from: hunger and fatigue, the two real devils in any civic story.

Autumn had the grace to pretend it was coming even in heat. The night market sold pears that women touched as if checking them for prophecy. The buses ran their knees automatically now, a courtesy upgraded to habit, and drivers had learned to do the motion with their left hand while their right hand did any of the thousand small acts that keep a bus from being a metaphor. Mr. Winn made a will in the lazy way that suggests a person does not intend to use it soon. She wrote down who would have the marbled notebook and who would have the thermos and who would have the basil when it went to seed properly and not in a panic. She did not tell her granddaughter that she had written the girl’s name on the inside cover because names confer obligation and teenagers have their own legislations about that. She put the will under the old cookbook that had been used solely as a trivet and felt the sense of it settle on her chest like a shawl she had not realized she wanted.

He walked by the dam and imagined again being the river’s editor. He put his fingers on the railing and felt the vibration like the thrum of a drum skin stretched too tight, and his mind went foolish with the fantasy of control. A man with a fishing license and shoulders like history stood twenty feet away and looked at him as if to say: what will you do with that little brush here, friend? He did nothing because men like him always mistake strategy for effect, and strategy requires the kindness of time, which he had spent already. He had begun talking to himself out loud in ways that made the maintenance crews look up from their brooms and then decide, with mercy, not to make faces. He went home to a room with a too-big chair and watched videos he should not, of women being clever with water and foil and breath, and he learned to be resentful of competence, the poorest of man’s hobbies.

The basil put out seed in a way that asked to be pinched and saved. Mr. Winn and her granddaughter stood in morning light with two envelopes stolen from the desk at the laundromat and the amiable theft felt like a sacrament. They rubbed the dried flowers between their fingers and the seeds fell like punctuation she would later object to if a student had used so many in a sentence. The girl wrote basil, roof, the date, and put the envelope to her nose and said it smelled like what you wish a pantry would smell like in novels. They watered with the last of the dishwater because everyone’s small economies had learned to take pride in being called by their right names. They pressed the envelopes flat and tucked them into the jar where rubber bands go to die and told each other a story about next spring in the way women do when they are deliberately betting against the odds.

At the clinic the hydrophilic film on the doors had begun to grow a fringe from tiny scratches made by keys and coin edges and the rings of hands that had loved too hard. The maintenance woman took the film off with the tenderness of a nurse and put on a new sheet with a roller that had been designed by someone who loved paint and dressed modestly. Mr. Winn watched her do it and applauded with hunger she refused to call hope, because if hope hears its own name too often it grows vain. The maintenance woman said, “We do the same amount whether or not anyone notices,” and Mr. Winn felt in her chest the good pain that arrives when someone says simple truth in a voice not interested in audience. They stood together afterward and looked at the glass pretending to be just glass, and both of them saw a kind of parish work where the sacrament is called attention.

He went to a sports store and bought a black umbrella because his had been taken, and when he opened it in his kitchen he felt theatrical and a little ashamed. He had lost the forest of applause he had once called a day and now he made do with oneself clapping in a kitchen with linoleum that remembered better shoes. He opened the umbrella in the park as a test and a woman in a visor told him he was inviting bad luck with an absentmindedness that felt like medicine in a pill. He walked into a wind that did not have the decency to be visible. The umbrella pulled at his arm like a stubborn pet. He folded it, unwilling to be a threat to no one’s ankles, and stood with his brush and his hum and his appetite and learned that there are days when the city will let you know that you are not required, and that those days are the ones that change a man far away from any camera.

In the evening, with the heat practicing how to be less rude and the smoke pretending to belong to another continent, Mr. Winn went to the bus stop and poured a thin line along the lip of the shelter because habit is where safety sleeps. She sat and counted buses kneeling, not because anyone had asked her to keep track, but because counting, like watering basil, forces a body to put hope into a sequence. A young man offered to give up his seat and she let him because his courtesy deserved practice. The driver lowered the bus for an invisible person down the block because this too had become ritual. The girl with the sparrow tattoo from the market came by with a mister clipped to her belt like a joke and said hello, Mr., as if the world had always been this ordinary. They talked about tomatoes and about the new drop pins that didn’t gleam but pleased anyway. Across the street the hydrophilic film did its work without anyone narrating it. The wind did what wind does with small bits of foil in a birch. The city moved around its own arteries with unremarkable grace. They had not won. They had continued. They had kept their instruments tuned. They had put their hands to the pumps and to the fans and to their own stubborn hearts and a chapter turned on that motion, as cleanly as a page.

Chapter 9

Autumn finally found its footing after so much summer that felt like a dare. The air came thin and edged, a blade for heat’s rope, and the smoke that had made the sky its rented room took down its curtains and apologized by way of distance. Leaves crisped to paper and then to lace and then to brown, and sound began to carry again in that mean way it has when the temperature drops—voices crossing streets they couldn’t manage in July, a door closing from half a block away like a punctuation mark louder than the sentence that required it. Mr. Winn listened to the city’s new clarity as if some orchestra had finally stopped tuning and chosen a key, and she found herself hearing the bus’s brakes with respect, the hiss at the end of the exhale being as honest a piece of music as she had ever asked to memorize.

The grid had sulked long enough that the council tried something that sounded like thrift and turned out to be ritual. They called it a Turn-Down Night and sent mailers with officious clip art asking neighborhoods to dim for two hours, the hour after sundown and the hour before bed, as if darkness were a chore to assign and not a condition to negotiate. Reaction had the cartoon predictability of any city: a man wrote to the paper to say this was civic theater and he did not audition for roles, a child drew a picture of stars and handed it to a librarian who pinned it to a corkboard with quiet ceremony, and volunteers got to work on the thing they always recognize in an announcement—the invitation buried inside a rule. Arkady posted a tone map on Stoneflower, a chart of small noises the city could lean into: fans set to oscillate instead of point, wind chimes made of spoons and Mylar that clicked like shy teeth, bicycle spokes with ribbons that whispered instead of shouted, radiators finally free to sing their winter song and being asked to sing on purpose.

He liked the thought of lowered lights as if the city were tipping its head for his hand. He polished the ferrule of a new brush with a rag that had once been a shirt someone loved and told himself the argument he always won when no one answered back: that darkness was a solvent and he, the man who could pour it. He studied a map with a finger that pretended it had gentleness and marked with his nail the places where dark pooled even on busy nights—the reading room at the west branch where lamps hung like planets, the memorial grove where names lived in bronze and the trees shushed any person with a thought of cheer. He hummed to test his own mood and heard in it the old complaint that music had failed him. He didn’t consider sound a thing that counted, because he had never had to listen.

The practice they made for Turn-Down Night began at the laundromat because everything had come to begin there, the hum of machines a forgiving bassline. A young woman whose degree said audio engineering and whose debts said barista brought little speakers the size of apples and set them on washers, and she played the kind of noise that isn’t a song but still feels like a choice. At low frequency the plexi they’d scrounged from behind an art room wrote small circles of condensation as if it were taking notes. They drew a brave, skinny line of his not-paint on the panel and watched it behave. Under certain tones it held itself like a lie that believes its own face; under others it loosened, feathered at the edges the way frost begins to admit it is only water pretending to be geometry. They learned that the hum of the building itself—the elevator’s muscle, the vents’ dry exhale, the old refrigerator’s honesty—made a modest current in air that the black disliked, not dramatical enough to post about but perfect for the stubbornness of living with a problem.

Turn-Down Night came dressed as festivity and stubborn practicality both. Streetlights bowed to half and porches went to lanterns and then to loud scolding by aunties who refused to let children be delighted by fire unsupervised. The bus’s interior lights dimmed to a polite amount and every driver in the city seemed to discover at the same moment that you could lower the bus knee with your foot and let that hiss be a metronome. In doorways hung bead curtains cut from old Mylar blankets that remembered marathons and here did a different kind of endurance. Fans in windows moved air like river wrists. The Hush Walk went out not with foil shining gaudy but with wind-bells made of keys that clicked a domestic holiness across the hands. They added breath to the list of tasks: breathe when the smear appears and breathe together, because exhale without chorus loses half its moral force.

He tried the memorial grove first because he liked to begin by stealing gravity. The names on the bronze had learned already to resist him; they had been washed so often now with the kind of care that looks like mourning that the black sulked at their edges and slid off in well-trained beads. He pressed the brush to the bench where a woman was peeling an orange for her father, the peel coming away in one elegant helix that suggested competence to the point of art. She did not flinch, not because she was brave but because she heard the key-bells in the path stir, the kind of sound you cannot quite locate, and she felt the smallest wind volunteer its disobedience along her forearm. The black reached without reaching and then stuttered the way a bad idea does when it encounters habit. His hum went to find itself and discovered with an emotion very close to insult that it had competition. From the path a group of teenagers carried their phones in their back pockets instead of their hands and let out a tone under their breath like lawnmowers over a hill, a brown noise that had gotten famous among insomniacs and now was a civic instrument, and on the plexi panel of the bus shelter the smear that had begun to arrange itself found it had no place to gather.

Côté arrived not with what the papers would call a weapon but with a joystick that controlled the oscillation of a fan he could not have explained to a judge without learning to love metaphor. He let the blade swing, not angrily but insistently, and the air wrote a discipline over the bench and the bronze that the brush could not count on. The church down the block had loaned a pipe from its organ to a child with good lungs and worse homework, and the sound they made when he blew was not reverent but was old, which suited the problem at hand. The black that had loved flat surfaces and single notes found itself being convinced into forgetting. He reached for a mirror mounted on a pole and drew, and the line he dragged behind his bristles tremored, lost track, and slipped as if embarrassed. He did not understand the holds of phase and anti-phase and it did not matter; his shadow learned to dislike being asked to keep time with anything but itself.

Mr. Winn walked with the crowd and let the noise wash the old stubbornness in her chest in a way that annoyed her by feeling too much like cure. Teddy made a small poor choice near the lamppost by the drugstore and then apologized, and she kept the breath pattern Lenka had taught her like a chant, two frogs on a summer ditch swapping places. Her granddaughter had one of the apple speakers clipped to her belt and had named the tone she preferred tonic because naming any tool dignifies the hand that wields it. She pressed a button with a thumb whose nail still had a smear of basil dirt at the quick and the sound that came hummed in the key of unremarkable buildings, a comfort noise. When the smear essayed itself onto the transit map like a thesis with too many adverbs, the girl stepped close, told the people near her not to mind, and let the pocket’s noise lie flat against the glass. The black went soft at the middle and then dissolved without drama. The girl lifted her chin and did not look for applause because she had learned from the women who were teaching that competence is dull to any eye not involved.

He took himself where no rituals had been practiced—he believed—into the new spa with a sign in a too-gentle font that offered sensory deprivation, which seemed to him, in a mood that surprised him by its honesty, like a place that might finally honor him without require an audience. The pods were eggs someone had forgotten to fill with stories, white on white on low whisper. He put his hand on the curve of one, the brush hovering, and his dark went ahead like an earnest scout. Water waited inside, not running, stilled into obedience by salt, and he had the sudden animal memory of the river refusing to admit him. The filter’s small motor made the tiniest of circulations, a current only a tadpole would brag about, and it was enough. The smear he had sent under the lid met that minuscule motion and failed to sit. It made the pod look unwashed but not unholy, and a woman with tired bones who had paid for an hour of quiet came in and saw the mark and went for a cloth with that tiredness born of a thousand small tidies, and she rubbed, humming because she had been taught in kindergarten to sing when you clean. He left angry at the shape of his own want.

Lenka wrote on Mr. Winn’s table with letters that would have earned a C for legibility and an A for content if Mr. Winn were still the kind of person who graded papers. Sound is a river if you ask it to be, she typed around the weak ribbon, and she drew in pencil three little waves like a girl making a map for a game. At the bottom she added, in the shame-hand she affected for her big thoughts, he hums in straight lines because he cannot help himself; give him a curve and he will lose his balance. Arkady took the thought and respun it into a guide for buildings, a habit list: let the vents oscillate, not fixed; run the fans with a sway; schedule the compressors for off-beats if the budget allows; ask janitors to stop halfway down a hall and then go back the other way for no reason they need explain to anyone. The note to the janitors went up on corkboards in break rooms like a promise no one wanted to admit they needed.

On buses, the kneeling hiss became a kind of call and response, drivers trading jokes about timing while their feet learned a choreography that let machines and people practice being gentle together. Museums leaned their humidity higher for paper and the added air moved grievances off glass in the manner of a polite usher. The nail salon put a playlist on that was mostly fans in different rooms and the women in the chairs laughed with a relief that should not have felt radical. The roller rink DJ discovered a track that was nothing but a subway car recorded from the end of the last car, a steady new river, and whenever she played it the black on the corners of mirrors sighed and forgot its shape. This did not make a headline and no one’s grant proposal got easier to write, but the city’s shoulders went down another inch and stayed there, a measure you could see only if you loved measurement for reasons that were not power.

Noise complaints filed in the week after the Turn-Down rose and fell like the stock market and the men who tally such things tried to find in the data a righteousness they could wear to a meeting. A baby down the hall from Indira discovered that crying into the foil curtain by the elevator made a sound that brought adults at speed, and the household kept the curtain there for a day longer than they needed to because you do not argue with a toddler whose experiment has worked. In the library the new maintenance man put the fans on too high and papers tried to animate themselves off tables, and in the fine for blowing on books column of crime and punishment, he earned a warning and then a pie someone had baked because the building had more gratitude than rules. They tuned and detuned and tuned again, less a policy than a musician’s grunt work.

In the marbled notebook, Mr. Winn wrote phase and then, because she could not help herself, drew a little sketch of two waves that met and made a straight line where a mess might have been, and she felt a smugness she would not confess to traffic reporters or to saints. She wrote: we starved him of stillness, which had the virtue of being truth and the limitation of being only partial. Under it she wrote: other hungers will find him. He will try to stand where nothing moves—fever, snow, words. She wrote: words move if you make them, and she looked at the page until the line turned into a field and then into a feathering she wanted to call frost and did not, because metaphor had been overworked this year and deserved a nap.

He went out past the last bus to the place where the forest pretended it had not heard of cities and put his hand on the bark of a pine he would never bother to name. The wind there said ocean without water, a language made of small noises en masse, and he felt his dark slip as if embarrassed to be the only thing holding still. Needles shivered and the sky between gave him a litter of pieces he could not assemble into a wall. He walked a path the color of argument and the sound of his own foot on duff made a music he had always despised, and he did nothing, which was new as a skill. He came back smaller not because anyone took anything from him but because scale is a function of frame and the frame had shifted in ways he did not know how to narrate to himself without breaking.

Bulbs went into rooftop tubs with the solemnity of translating something ancient. They planted tulips and then decided on daffodils because daffodils forgive more. Indira and Mr. Winn dug with spoons because the trowel had gone on walkabout and returned as a superhero cape for a doll downstairs and they refused to fight that rescue mission with an adult’s need to own. They tucked the papery bulbs into that mix of dirt and old coffee that every city gardener eventually perfects, and they talked about the way sound had felt as a tool the night before, not as victory but as rehearsal. They watered with brown water that had washed hands and then forgotten that it had, and to the little bump of earth where a tulip slept they told the story of a bus kneeling as a kind of lullaby.

At the pool the audio engineer and Arkady and four kids who had spent their childhoods making phones serve as drums set up a speaker low enough to be mistaken for negligence and curled the sound around the water like a ribbon and watched the surface write commas. They drew a line on plexi again, because tests require repetition to admit to themselves that they are not lucky, and let a tone that tasted like rain in a parking garage ask the black to un-tell its own story. It did, grudgingly. One of the kids asked whether laughter counted as noise and the audio engineer told him yes and the pool echoed yes yes until they had to fetch the whistle because joy, too, needs shepherding when it’s near water.

He made himself speak again, poorly. He had never been a man who kept diaries because diaries do not clap, and the phone in his hand became a confession booth without priest. He said into the lens, “You make a trick out of motion,” and the phone did not argue and did not agree and did not go out of its way to find him an audience. The algorithm did not love him like he believed it should. The comments he read later were tired and practical, women trading fan settings and telling each other which sound machines broke after two months and which ones lasted, and he felt, for the first time perhaps in a life that had had plenty of opportunity for the feeling, truly irrelevant. He mistook that poverty for injustice.

When the pumps in the three oldest buildings decided to take the same day off—perhaps in a solidarity learned in pipes that shook toward each other through soil—Mr. Winn and Indira and a boy who had found the trowel ribbon in the pocket of his hoodie moved water without believing it made them saints. Côté drove a boxy city van badly up a narrow lane because permission did not come with skill, and he and two other men who had expected their hands to write tickets and not carry cases of bottles invented a relay that did not require applause. At the end of the corridor that smelled of institutions and dinners, someone had drawn a line two nights ago and a woman who carried a baby the fussy size of a loaf of bread took a patience she could not afford and poured a streak of her ration along it as if drawing a line between mischief and home. It lifted, shame-faced. She went on.

He tried snow when it came, because snow is a pause with edges, and he liked edges. He pressed the brush to the plexi of a bus shelter grown brittle with cold. The line he drew tried to be himself and then fell onto the snow on the sill and made a dull collusion with white that read as stain and not as doctrine. A volunteer in a hat long enough to be described, in older novels, as knitted with love, breathed, and the breath fogged and then fell as tiny rivulets of perfectly ordinary wet. The smear unmade itself with a laziness that felt like cruelty. He laughed in a way that broke something inside whatever the black used for pride.

At the council chamber with its flags that had never learned to drape with grace, they argued about noise in a way that would have made summer Mr. Winn impatient and now only tickled her in the way of small absurdities. The first-to-know councilor floated the idea of appointing a Director of Sound and was surprised when the room did not mock her. The Public Works woman said, “We already have one; it is the wind,” and then, because she had learned to dress the truth in a blazer, added, “and also my department, on Thursdays,” and they laughed with their shoulders and then wrote a line into a document that would outlast any of them and it said more or less: buildings will be invited to move air. It was an invitation like many the city had grown good at writing—it sounded soft until you felt the hand behind it.

Mr. Winn went home and made tea and forgot the kettle on and remembered it in time and wrote in the marbled book the sentences she allowed herself when the city had pleased her and, in pleasing, made her suspicious. She wrote: do not love your tools so much you forget to put them down. She wrote: when he stops moving, do not write a ballad. She wrote: practice is the only magic we are allowed. Teddy made a little jump in agreement or disapproval; it was hard to tell. The basil on the sill gave up at last, its leaves despairing of pretending to be green, and she cut what could be cut and dried it on a plate she had saved from the old country’s thrift store because being poor at the right time is how you end a day.

He stood at the window of his room in a building that had pretended to be fashionable and failed and watched a bus lower for an empty stop and he did not sneer. He did not admire, either; he was not ready for that. Down the block a woman shook out a cloth and the cloth made a wave of air the size of her kitchen and the black in the corner of the window frame retreated without narrative. He felt anger in his knees the way men do when they are slowly being asked to learn they are not the protagonist, and he put his brush in a jar and for a second made the mistake of thinking that a gesture is a choice. The jar was clean. The brush stayed a brush. The city moved around him with a competence that did not ask permission. The Turn-Down ended without anyone besides the council and a few poets noting it, and the lights went back up to their small arrogant levels, and the fans kept moving because motion, once it is learned, is reluctant to forget itself.

Chapter 10

Winter tried on sincerity and then committed, and the city adjusted its jaw the way you do when a new filling reminds you there is a mouth inside the face you present. The river put on a sheet in places where it was shallow, a brittle pretense, and kept its muscle where depth made stubbornness academic. The air sharpened into the kind of attention that never suits liars, and sounds travelled as if hired for the job—skate blades farther along the path than you could account for, the far-off drill that Public Works wielded against a bolt which had decided it was married. Mr. Winn learned the creaks in her building again, winter’s specific chorus, and found that the radiator’s song had a kindness in it she had failed to recognize as a child. It was not music, not really; it was function so steadfast that it bothered to be audible.

Stoneflower wrote in threads not of panic but of phase, a handful of physicists with kindness in their fonts explaining how water, obedient mostly to heat, could be coaxed into disobedience by motion even when the calendar tried to fix it. A woman from the parks department with calves like the roots of a tree posted photographs of bubblers the city had forgotten it owned, little machines meant for ornamental ponds now reinterpreted as river breath. Volunteers borrowed the word aeration and made it a civic endearment. They asked the fountain that had spat half-hearted rainbows in the plaza all summer to use its lungs to keep the underpass from glazing into something his not-paint would love. A man with a plow route longer than some family trees found himself consenting to drag a chain behind the truck just to scratch the ice into a thousand lines, which is another way of saying he had been taught to make surface unconfident.

He went for ice with the stubborn curiosity of someone who has had a favorite table taken away and must discover whether the new one will hold his elbows. At the river’s edge where the water had decided to pretend it was floor, he pressed the brush and watched the black scud across slickness and try to be a face. The cold did not respect his appetite. It seized the skin of the stain at the edges and made it look like a bruise pretending to be architecture. A child in a too-big parka with pompoms like modest planets skated close, mother at a distance, and her blades made their own sound like careful tearing, and the black tremored wherever she passed as if the idea of glide had embarrassed it. He tried to write longer and the city’s small interventions, salt and grit and chain scratches and a bubbler twenty feet downstream pushing its insistence through the field, turned his line into confetti that could not decide whether it wanted to be ink or ash.

In Mr. Winn’s kitchen, Teddy chose to send stern notes at inconvenient hours and had to be answered with breath and patience and Indira’s hands with their small, competent heat. The granddaughter learned the inventory of pills and the inventory of jokes that worked no matter how scared a room became, and she practiced not overperforming either. They set up new rituals alongside the old ones: a check of the misters’ hoses coiled for spring, a glance at the fan in the hallway to ensure oscillation did not die under the weight of laziness, a tally kept in the marbled book of days when she could make it to the bus stop and pour a thin line and days when the window must be her observation deck. She told herself boredom was still a weapon and that it had to be shared to be sharp.

The reading room at West Branch put out an advisory in the plainest tone it had: please do not breathe on the vellum. They turned the pages anyway, librarians with the good hands, and found they had built a weather that defended memory. He entered with his hum down low and the dark sitting like a folded coat around him and aimed at a display case so proud of its carefulness it had grown humble. The case, as it turned out, was an instrument too; its microclimate put a slow circulation on the air that lifted a smear’s edges and weathered it into an accident. Librarians became ornithologists of smudge and learned to identify the species at a glance. They set the humidifiers not at stasis but at a practiced sway and forced his certainty to try to find purchase on a surface writing its own small poem of ebb and return. A page turned across the room made a draft that was not drama but was doctrine, and the black retreated, offended without admitting to offense because it preferred to think of its sensitivities as power.

The city rediscovered readings as if someone had thrown a cue. Not the sponsored kind with wine in plastic cups and jackets that needed tending; the stubborn kind in laundromats and bus depots and clinic vestibules, where grandparents took turns making words into weather for children who had forgotten their scarves. They learned to read out loud not because it made anyone clever but because it moved the air where breath sometimes failed to collect. Lines of poetry, yes, when somebody wanted to be tender, but grocery lists too, a woman reciting in bored reverence the inventory she had to face and letting that cadence set up a current in the hallway. Students stood in a circle under bead curtains and chanted multiplication tables as if they were invoking something older than numbers, and the smear on the wall behind them relented despondently in the face of rhythm. A man with a bad day read his appliance manual for a toaster over the heads of strangers waiting for a bus and the laugh that went through the shelter did exactly what was required.

At the dam the bubbler team learned to ask for overtime without apology and Public Works discovered it could borrow parts from places the budget had not thought to categorize as cousins. The men who had names stitched in blue on their shirts became heroes by refusing the word and showing up with tools that clicked and whined and turned deep water from a mirror into an argument. A heron watched from a sill of ice with the professional resignation of a bird that knows it has outlived fashions. He came to the wall and counted bolts like prayers he never liked and told himself a story about leverage that admitted no mathematicians. He pressed the brush to the railing as if to sign it and discovered that the salt that kept human feet honest had left a wet that would not keep secrets, and the line he drew forgot itself on contact with the film only City Hall would ever learn the procurement number for. He withdrew with dignity and that, perhaps, was the beginning of a new humiliation for him; he could not even give himself to fury with any hope of applause to make it worth the cost.

Lenka made soup and called it conveyance because nothing else that day had gone where it should. She carried the pot across a hallway to Mr. Winn’s door, dish towel wrapped in that particular grandma architecture that prevents burns but looks like ritual. They ate and let steam be a tool, lids lifted and replaced until the windows remembered what winter does to glass, and afterward she typed poorly about betrayals she had seen in other towns where men of a similar appetite had tried to turn stillness into territory. In the margin she penciled a note because the ribbon had finally cracked itself into silence: steam carries; enlist it when you can. The laundromat took the sentence literally and put a kettle behind the coin machine to warm the room’s air in enough cycles that fog became ordinance.

He tried the subway, in the hour when trains ran like promises kept grudgingly, and put his hand out into the piston wind that tunnels generate for free. He had always held contempt for the kind of movement that does not originate in a human hand and here found himself, to his surprise, resentful of steel. The smear he sent ahead of himself made it three feet before the gust ran its fingers through it and unmade it into suggestion. Students, noses pink with cold above their masks, did not offer him a glance. A busker at the turnstile played the same three bars on a violin with a determination that would have made saints rueful, and the ruins of his line on a tile wall adopted the rhythm against their will until they were more accompaniment than inscription.

Screens, which he had scorned because they belong to a species of attention that refuses to be shared with anything but itself, betrayed him with updates. The e-ink timetables in the transit shelters refreshed in that little shiver you have to look for deliberately, and his not-paint could not keep its grip on a surface that insisted on the small polite chaos of changing digits. He tried his line down the edge where the advertisement had been put under glass no thicker than a fingernail, and the hydrophilic film lifted water from air to meet him with a thin slick handshake that left him feeling like a man who has been given a pamphlet when he had demanded a sword. His hum rose in irritation and was met by a child practicing a recorder wrong on purpose, and for the first time he considered taking offense at a note.

Turn-Down became Turn-Over became habit. They made schedules for the oscillations of air instead of for the delivery of spectacle, and the flyers that went out to building supers had diagrams that looked like dances drawn by a careful hand that did not like to admit to art. The Office of Motion—the joke title the Public Works woman had put on a note as sarcasm and then stamped on a memo as if that had been the plan all along—started to send bulletins written in the voice of an aunt: do not forget to let your fans rest between stretches, darlings, because machines have the tempers of middle children. Mr. Winn saved those notices with the reverence she reserved for recipes written in other women’s hands and taped them inside a cupboard door she opened twice a day because ritual improves if it is near flour.

There were setbacks of the small, true sort, the kind a novelist would remove for cleanliness and a city must keep to avoid myth. A volunteer slipped on the thin film that comes when ambition meets a cheap mop and sprained an already tired ankle. A bubbler seized and coughed oil like a gossip and had to be taken apart on a night cold enough to make men swear in languages they didn’t know they knew. A man whose temperament tended toward argument took a fan’s oscillation as an insult and calmed down only when the custodian let him put a hand on the grille to feel the reality of appliance instead of the suspicion of plan. A teen with a bright appetite for drama filmed himself trying to make the black hold on a frosted window and got three likes and a text from a girl who told him he was being predictable and he went to the rink instead. The obituary column in the paper—the column no one wants and everyone requires—made a small lean toward the ordinary that winter, and the city let itself be grateful without sending a self-congratulatory note to itself.

On the roof the basil had given up and the bulbs slept in their paper coats, and the two women who had planted them tried not to look like people at a bedside. They shook dry seed into envelopes and dated them as if spring could be called to attention by a stamp. Mr. Winn told the story of her father’s hands again, because repetition is one of age’s rewards, and the granddaughter asked for it in the way of teenagers who pretend that they are submitting more than requesting. She made tea and got the water just short of boiling because herbs are snobs, and when they drank it it tasted like the shadow of a summer in a city that had had to relearn every choreography it thought had gone out of fashion.

He went back to the river not because he had any hope of conquering it but because misery, like worship, is repetitive. He walked to the place where the ice showed off in a lilac that would have delighted him if he had had room in his attention for any color but his own, and he put the brush in the pocket of his coat and did not take it out. The fog lifted in a single line from a breathe-hole where the bubbler worked and he stepped into it by accident, a joke written by physics and not by anyone’s agenda. His coat gathered damp and his shadow, which had always believed itself exempt, recoiled with the skittishness of a horse surprised by its own reflection. He stood a long time and the only witness was a woman he did not see who had come with a thermos to practice her own ritual, and she poured a thin line along the lip of the path and did not look at him because withholding that last dignity had become a civic sport.

The council posed for a photograph none of them would print, a group of people with their faces in honest winter disarray standing in front of a box of fans and a spool of Mylar and a crate of replacement humidifier filters that held the true glamour of any season. They passed a resolution no one would call a law because the word law makes people stand up straighter than necessary: buildings, public and private, are requested to move air. The city clerk wrote it into language that would not be laughed at by anyone who counts commas, and the maintenance crews nodded because it meant someone had noticed their empire. The marketing firm tried to design a poster declaring Sound Saves and Arkady wrote a note that said, as gently as she knew how, please stop giving us slogans; we have enough to hold in our mouths.

Mr. Winn found herself saving ridiculous things that winter—rubber bands with their bloom of starch, the twist tie from bread, the label peeled off a jar because the glue was obedient and it felt like disloyalty to throw away any honest labor. Her heart behaved itself more often than she had any right to expect, and when it did not, the drills of breath and quiet and practiced boredom did what drills do: they made a skill out of panic’s bad impulse. She wrote in the marbled book sentences she would have dismissed as trite in a classroom and found them to be, in a kitchen, exact. You can be tired and still be useful. You can be afraid and still be courteous. You can be unimportant and still be necessary. Indira found the book open one afternoon and added in her own hand, slanted and decisive, you can be wrong and try again without ceremony.

The man whose darkness had learned reluctance took a bus one afternoon not because he had chosen humility but because the car he had counted on was sulking under a thin coat of ice that made tires into advice nobody wanted. He sat two rows back and watched the driver work the knee of the machine for an old man carrying celery and for a girl with a backpack that made the alphabet look newly minted, and in the rhythm of the bus he felt something he did not have a name for because the names available to him had been stolen by people he had refused to watch. The hydrophilic film on the glass behind the ad that showed a woman with a hammer and a smile was scratched but useful, and the little bead chain on the stop request bell knocked a rhythm against the pole that made the shadow at his heel jitter into a species of shyness. He got off not because it was his stop but because the bus had made itself into a room that did not need him.

There was a night colder than the year deserved, and the fans stuttered in their bearings and the bubbler complained like an old man, and the people who had made a habit out of mercy did what habits are for and did not abandon their post. A boy with bad gloves took the midnight shift at the rink because the generator needed to be fed and the fog had to be kept from lying down flat, and he sang to himself without knowing the building could hear him and approve. A woman on the hospital’s third floor who had spent her career mending the small holes left by the city in the bodies of its citizens watched the hydrophilic film carry the smallest of beads along its face and thought, ungodly for a minute, that if there were a god this might be how grace chose to move.

When spring’s first rumor came not in bud but in smell—a sour wet at the seams of the sidewalks where snow had hunkered and homesickness had gone to winter—the city had enough practice not to mistake rumor for arrival. The bulbs in the roof tubs did the math on light and decided to be patient, and the basil envelope stayed in the jar as if a seed can tell time by paper. He went looking for a new surface with a man’s temper for having to adapt and found none that would restore him to the scale he had once bullied the city into granting. He stood at a bus shelter and watched a volunteer wipe, not in circles, but in lines taught by the Office of Motion, because circles coddle a smear and lines make it travel, and he felt not hatred but the pettier thing that rots quicker: envy of competence.

On an evening when the sky had the clean marrow-blue of polite cold and Mr. Winn counted the kneels at the stop without the craving to make the number round off into a legend, a woman in a visor who had scolded him for opening an umbrella in a park months ago came to sit and said nothing and then said, after two stops had gone by, that her boy slept better to brown noise and she had bought a machine that did the job well. Mr. Winn told her she was an engineer whether or not anyone had hired her. The hydrophilic film did its quiet trick one more time on an attempt that would not be broadcast because the city had finally gotten good at starve. The keys in the bead curtain at the laundromat clicked a note that had become a civic pitch. The river, under ice in places and not in others, remembered what water is and refused to be hired by anybody’s story. They sat and let the bus make its kneeling music and counted only for themselves, because a ritual without a congregation is sometimes the clearest kind.
